1.meaning_en: A shortened form of a word or phrase.
usage_sentences: Please use the full name instead of the abbreviation.
'Dr.' is a common abbreviation for 'Doctor'.

1.meaning_en: To increase in speed or rate.
usage_sentences: The driver had to accelerate to overtake the truck.
The government plans to accelerate economic growth.

1.meaning_en: Agreement; harmony; to grant or concede.
usage_sentences: The two nations finally reached a peace accord.
His actions were not in accord with his words.
1.origin: From Latin 'accordare', meaning 'to be of one heart'.

1.meaning_en: A person who keeps or inspects financial accounts.
usage_sentences: The company hired an accountant to manage its finances.
An accountant must be precise and detail-oriented.
1.origin: From Old French 'aconter', meaning 'to account, reckon'.

1.meaning_en: A thing done; a deed; to perform an action.
usage_sentences: His last act was one of great kindness.
It's time to act and make a decision.

1.meaning_en: To make something active or operative.
usage_sentences: You need to enter the code to activate the software.
The smoke detector will activate if it senses fire.

1.meaning_en: Inspiring great affection; delightful; charming.
usage_sentences: The little puppy was absolutely adorable.
She wore an adorable dress to the party.

1.meaning_en: Ready or likely to attack or confront; characterized by forceful behavior.
usage_sentences: The company launched an aggressive marketing campaign.
His aggressive behavior made others uncomfortable.

1.meaning_en: A collection of recordings, photographs, or other items.
usage_sentences: She showed me her old family photo album.
The band's new album will be released next month.

1.meaning_en: The height of an object or point in relation to sea level or ground level.
usage_sentences: The aircraft was flying at a high altitude.
Mountain climbers often struggle with the effects of high altitude.

1.meaning_en: An accredited diplomat sent by a country as its official representative.
usage_sentences: The Indian ambassador to the United States attended the meeting.
She was appointed as a cultural ambassador for the organization.
1.origin: From Old French 'ambassadeur', from a Germanic word related to 'official'.

1.meaning_en: Lacking a moral sense; unconcerned with the rightness or wrongness of something.
usage_sentences: A purely scientific decision can be seen as amoral.
The character in the book was a cold, amoral person.

1.meaning_en: Cold-blooded vertebrate animals that live both on land and in water.
usage_sentences: Frogs and salamanders are common amphibians.
Amphibians typically lay their eggs in water.
1.origin: From Greek 'amphibios', meaning 'living a double life'.

1.meaning_en: Detailed examination of the elements or structure of something.
usage_sentences: A detailed analysis of the data revealed some interesting trends.
The doctor is waiting for the lab analysis.

1.meaning_en: A heavy object used to moor a vessel; to secure firmly in position.
usage_sentences: The ship dropped its anchor in the harbor.
She is the anchor of our news program.

1.meaning_en: Belonging to the very distant past and no longer in existence.
usage_sentences: We visited the ancient ruins in Greece.
The museum has a collection of ancient artifacts.
1.origin: From Old French 'ancien', based on Latin 'ante' meaning 'before'.

1.meaning_en: The date on which an event took place in a previous year.
usage_sentences: They celebrated their 25th wedding anniversary last week.
The company will mark its 50th anniversary next year.

1.meaning_en: A word opposite in meaning to another.
usage_sentences: 'Hot' is the antonym of 'cold'.
The teacher asked the students to find the antonym for 'happy'.

1.meaning_en: Express regret for something done or said.
usage_sentences: You should apologize for your rude behavior.
He later apologized for his mistake.
1.origin: From Greek 'apologia', meaning 'a speech in one's own defense'.

1.meaning_en: A person who makes a formal application for something.
usage_sentences: There were over a hundred applicants for the job.
Each applicant must submit a resume and a cover letter.

1.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of water.
usage_sentences: Due to his aquaphobia, he never learned how to swim.
A therapist helped him overcome his aquaphobia.

1.meaning_en: A tank of water in which fish and other aquatic creatures are kept.
usage_sentences: The children love to watch the colorful fish in the aquarium.
We visited the city's public aquarium.

1.meaning_en: Relating to water; living in or near water.
usage_sentences: Dolphins are aquatic mammals.
The pond is full of aquatic plants.

1.meaning_en: A person who creates art.
usage_sentences: The artist displayed her paintings at the gallery.
He is a talented artist who works with both paint and sculpture.

1.meaning_en: A person who studies the movements of celestial bodies to predict the future.
usage_sentences: The astrologer read her horoscope and made a prediction.
Many people consult an astrologer before making big decisions.

1.meaning_en: The study of celestial bodies' movements to predict human affairs.
usage_sentences: She has a deep interest in astrology and reads her horoscope daily.
Astrology is considered a pseudoscience by many.

1.meaning_en: A person trained to travel in a spacecraft.
usage_sentences: Neil Armstrong was the first astronaut to walk on the moon.
Becoming an astronaut requires years of rigorous training.

1.meaning_en: The scientific study of celestial objects.
usage_sentences: He is a professor of astronomy at the university.
Astronomy has made incredible discoveries about the universe.

1.meaning_en: Able to be heard.
usage_sentences: His whisper was barely audible in the quiet room.
The sound was just audible above the noise of the traffic.

1.meaning_en: Of undisputed origin; genuine.
usage_sentences: The museum certified the painting as an authentic masterpiece.
This restaurant serves authentic Italian cuisine.

1.meaning_en: An account of a person's life written by that person.
usage_sentences: Mahatma Gandhi's autobiography is titled 'The Story of My Experiments with Truth'.
She wrote a fascinating autobiography about her time as a diplomat.

1.meaning_en: Keep away from or stop oneself from doing (something).
usage_sentences: You should avoid eating junk food to stay healthy.
He took a different route to avoid the traffic jam.
1.origin: From Old French 'esvuidier', meaning 'to empty out'.

1.meaning_en: An unmarried man; a person who holds a first degree from a university.
usage_sentences: He is a 30-year-old bachelor living in the city.
She has a Bachelor of Arts degree in history.
1.origin: From Old French 'bacheler', referring to a young knight or squire.

1.meaning_en: A place where bread and cakes are made or sold.
usage_sentences: The smell of fresh bread from the bakery was tempting.
I bought a birthday cake from the local bakery.
1.origin: From the verb 'bake', derived from Old English 'bacan'.

1.meaning_en: Having a scalp wholly or partly lacking hair.
usage_sentences: He started going bald in his early twenties.
The bald eagle is the national bird of the United States.
1.origin: From Middle English 'balled', possibly from a Celtic word.

1.meaning_en: Unable to pay one's debts; a person declared insolvent.
usage_sentences: The company went bankrupt after years of losses.
He was declared bankrupt and lost his house.

1.meaning_en: An instrument measuring atmospheric pressure.
usage_sentences: The barometer indicates that a storm is approaching.
A falling barometer often predicts bad weather.

1.meaning_en: A building or group of buildings used to house soldiers.
usage_sentences: The soldiers returned to their barracks after the training exercise.
Life in the barracks was strictly disciplined.

1.meaning_en: A cylindrical container bulging out in the middle.
usage_sentences: The wine was aged in oak barrels.
A barrel of oil contains about 42 gallons.

1.meaning_en: A person who gives money or other help to a person or cause.
usage_sentences: An anonymous benefactor donated a large sum to the hospital.
The university was founded by a wealthy benefactor.

1.meaning_en: A person who derives advantage from something, especially a trust, will, or life insurance policy.
usage_sentences: He was the main beneficiary of his uncle's will.
The charity is a beneficiary of the fundraising event.

1.meaning_en: A list of books referred to in a scholarly work.
usage_sentences: The research paper included a long bibliography of sources.
Always check the bibliography for further reading.

1.meaning_en: Passionate enthusiasm for collecting and possessing books.
usage_sentences: His bibliomania led him to spend his entire fortune on rare first editions.
What started as a hobby turned into full-blown bibliomania.

1.meaning_en: A person who loves or collects books.
usage_sentences: As a true bibliophile, she had a library in every room of her house.
The old bookstore was a paradise for bibliophiles.

1.meaning_en: The two-hundredth anniversary of a significant event.
usage_sentences: The city celebrated its bicentennial with a grand parade.
A special stamp was issued for the nation's bicentennial.
1.origin: From Latin 'bi-' (two) and 'centennial' (relating to a hundred years).

1.meaning_en: Taking place every two years; an event occurring every two years.
usage_sentences: The art exhibition is a biennial event.
Many plants have a biennial life cycle.

1.meaning_en: Speaking two languages fluently.
usage_sentences: Being bilingual is a great advantage in the modern world.
She grew up in a bilingual household, speaking both French and English.

1.meaning_en: Occurring every two months or twice a month.
usage_sentences: The committee holds bimonthly meetings.
That magazine is published bimonthly.

1.meaning_en: Capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms.
usage_sentences: We should use biodegradable packaging to protect the environment.
Paper and food waste are biodegradable.

1.meaning_en: An account of someone's life written by someone else.
usage_sentences: Walter Isaacson's biography of Albert Einstein is highly acclaimed.
She is writing a biography of the famous artist.

2.meaning_en: The study of living organisms.
usage_sentences: She is majoring in biology at the university.
Biology helps us understand the natural world.

2.meaning_en: The act of speaking sacrilegiously about God or sacred things.
usage_sentences: He was accused of blasphemy for his controversial statements.
In ancient times, blasphemy was a crime punishable by death.

2.meaning_en: Very strange or unusual.
usage_sentences: He had a bizarre dream about talking animals.
The whole situation was too bizarre to be believed.

2.meaning_en: To attack continuously with bombs or anything.
usage_sentences: The enemy forces began to bombard the city.
After the speech, she was bombarded with questions from reporters.
2.origin: From French 'bombarder', related to the sound of a bomb.

2.meaning_en: An extra amount of money added to someone's wages as a reward.
usage_sentences: The employees received a Christmas bonus.
As a bonus, the hotel offered a free breakfast.

2.meaning_en: A person who spends a lot of time reading.
usage_sentences: My sister is a real bookworm; she reads at least three books a week.
The library is the favorite haunt of every bookworm.
2.origin: A compound of 'book' and 'worm', likening a reader's devotion to a worm burrowing through pages.

2.meaning_en: To take and use something that belongs to someone else with the intention of returning it.
usage_sentences: Can I borrow your pen for a moment?
He had to borrow money from the bank to buy a car.
2.origin: From Old English 'borgian', meaning 'to take on credit'.

2.meaning_en: The scientific study of plants.
usage_sentences: She is an expert in the field of botany.
Botany is a branch of biology.

2.meaning_en: A situation that causes delay in a process or system.
usage_sentences: The narrow bridge is a major bottleneck for traffic in the city.
Lack of funding created a bottleneck in the project's progress.
2.origin: Metaphorical, from the narrow neck of a bottle that slows down the flow of liquid.

2.meaning_en: An act of breaking or failing to observe a law.
usage_sentences: This was a clear breach of the contract.
There was a serious security breach and data was stolen.

2.meaning_en: Hard but liable to break or shatter easily.
usage_sentences: Old plastic can become very brittle and break easily.
The thin glass was extremely brittle.
2.origin: From an Old English word related to 'break'.

2.meaning_en: The process of creating a plan to spend money.
usage_sentences: Effective budgeting is key to financial stability.
She is teaching her children about the importance of budgeting.
2.origin: From 'budget', which comes from Old French 'bougette', a small leather pouch.

2.meaning_en: A collection of things tied or wrapped together; to tie or wrap together.
usage_sentences: He carried a bundle of newspapers under his arm.
The company offers a software bundle at a discounted price.

2.meaning_en: A system of government in which most of the important decisions are made by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
usage_sentences: It took months to get the permit due to the endless bureaucracy.
He criticized the government for its excessive bureaucracy.

2.meaning_en: A low continuous humming or murmuring sound of bee or housefly.
usage_sentences: I could hear the buzz of a bee near the flowers.
There was a buzz of excitement in the room.

2.meaning_en: The young of a cow or other large mammal.
usage_sentences: The mother cow was very protective of her calf.
A young whale is also called a calf.

2.meaning_en: A person who eats the flesh of other human beings.
usage_sentences: Stories of cannibal tribes have fascinated and horrified people for centuries.
The explorers were afraid of being captured by cannibals.
2.origin: From Spanish 'Canibales', a name for the Carib people of the West Indies.

2.meaning_en: A wealthy person who uses money to invest in trade and industry for profit.
usage_sentences: He is a successful capitalist with investments in many industries.
The book discusses the role of the capitalist in a market economy.
2.origin: From 'capital', derived from Latin 'capitalis' meaning 'of the head'.

2.meaning_en: A doctor who specializes in the study or treatment of heart diseases.
usage_sentences: After his heart attack, he was referred to a cardiologist.
The cardiologist recommended changes to his diet and lifestyle.

2.meaning_en: The branch of medicine that deals with the heart and its diseases.
usage_sentences: She is studying cardiology at medical school.
Advances in cardiology have saved many lives.

2.meaning_en: Animals that feed on flesh.
usage_sentences: Lions, tigers, and wolves are all carnivores.
The fossilized teeth suggest the dinosaur was a carnivore.

2.meaning_en: A simple drawing showing the features of its subjects in a humorously exaggerated way.
usage_sentences: The children wake up early to watch their favorite cartoon.
The newspaper published a political cartoon criticizing the government.

2.meaning_en: A small waterfall, typically one of several that fall in stages down a steep rocky slope; to fall in or like a cascade.
usage_sentences: Water flowed down the rocks in a beautiful cascade.
Her long hair fell in a cascade over her shoulders.

2.meaning_en: A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
usage_sentences: The enzyme acted as a catalyst in the biological reaction.
His speech was the catalyst for social change.

2.meaning_en: An event causing great and often sudden damage or suffering; a disaster.
usage_sentences: The earthquake was a terrible catastrophe for the city.
Losing his job was a personal catastrophe.

2.meaning_en: Involving or causing sudden great damage or suffering.
usage_sentences: The oil spill had catastrophic consequences for the environment.
A catastrophic failure in the engine caused the plane to crash.

2.meaning_en: A temporary suspension of fighting; a truce.
usage_sentences: The two sides agreed to a temporary ceasefire.
Negotiations for a permanent ceasefire are underway.
2.origin: A compound of 'cease' (to stop) and 'fire' (shooting of weapons).

2.meaning_en: Pursue in order to catch or catch up with; an act of chasing.
usage_sentences: The police car had to chase the speeding vehicle.
The dog loves to chase balls in the park.
2.origin: From Old French 'chacier', from Latin 'captiare' (to try to seize).

2.meaning_en: A person who composes the sequence of steps and moves for a performance of dance.
usage_sentences: The choreographer taught the dancers the new routine.
She is a famous choreographer in the ballet world.

2.meaning_en: Relating to the order in which events happened.
usage_sentences: Please arrange the files in chronological order.
The book gives a chronological account of the war.

2.meaning_en: The arrangement of events or dates in the order of their occurrence.
usage_sentences: The historian established the chronology of the ancient dynasty.
It is difficult to determine the exact chronology of the events.

2.meaning_en: The part of the land near the sea; to move easily without using power.
usage_sentences: We went for a long walk along the coast.
He turned off the engine and let the car coast down the hill.

2.meaning_en: Persuade (an unwilling person) to do something by using force or threats.
usage_sentences: He claimed he was coerced into signing the confession.
You should not coerce someone into making a decision.

2.meaning_en: The practice of persuading someone to do something by using force or threats.
usage_sentences: A confession obtained by coercion is not admissible in court.
He signed the document under coercion.

2.meaning_en: A remarkable concurrence of events or circumstances without apparent causal connection.
usage_sentences: It was a strange coincidence that we were both in Paris at the same time.
By sheer coincidence, they were wearing the same dress.
2.origin: From Medieval Latin 'coincidentia', from 'co-' (together) and 'incidere' (to fall upon).

2.meaning_en: People with whom one works, especially in a profession or office.
usage_sentences: He went out for lunch with his colleagues from work.
She is highly respected by her colleagues.

2.meaning_en: An instruction, command, or duty given to a person or group of people; to formally choose someone to do a special piece of work.
usage_sentences: The government set up a commission to investigate the accident.
He earns a 10% commission on every sale he makes.
2.origin: From Latin 'commissio(n-)', from the verb 'committere' (to entrust).

2.meaning_en: Sympathetic pity and concern for the sufferings or misfortunes of others.
usage_sentences: She showed great compassion for the poor and the sick.
A good nurse must have compassion for their patients.

2.meaning_en: A thing that completes or brings to perfection; to add to something in a way that enhances or improves it.
usage_sentences: The wine was a perfect complement to the spicy food.
His skills complement hers, making them a great team.

2.meaning_en: Circles or arcs that share the same center.
usage_sentences: Dropping a stone in water creates a series of concentric ripples.
The target was made of several concentric circles.

2.meaning_en: Admit or state that one has committed a crime or is at fault in some way.
usage_sentences: The suspect finally decided to confess to the crime.
I must confess that I haven't finished the book yet.

2.meaning_en: An arrangement of elements in a particular form, figure, or combination.
usage_sentences: You can change the configuration of the seating to suit your needs.
The computer's default configuration can be customized.

2.meaning_en: Informal talk between two or more people.
usage_sentences: They had long conversations about their future plans.
Meaningful conversations can strengthen a relationship.

2.meaning_en: Averse to change or innovation and holding traditional values; a person who is averse to change.
usage_sentences: Her parents are very conservative in their views.
He made a conservative estimate of the costs.

2.meaning_en: Comfort (someone) at a time of grief or disappointment; a panel or unit accommodating a set of controls.
usage_sentences: We tried to console her after her dog died.
He spent the afternoon playing on his new gaming console.

2.meaning_en: A secret plan by a group to do something unlawful or harmful.
usage_sentences: They were accused of conspiracy to overthrow the government.
There are many conspiracy theories about the assassination.
2.origin: From Latin 'conspirare', meaning 'to agree, to plot'.

2.meaning_en: A group of stars forming a recognizable pattern.
usage_sentences: Orion is one of the most famous constellations in the night sky.
The ancient Greeks named many of the constellations.

2.meaning_en: Made impure by exposure to or addition of a poisonous or polluting substance.
usage_sentences: The city's water supply was contaminated with chemicals.
Do not eat food from a contaminated area.

2.meaning_en: Living or occurring at the same time; a person or thing living or existing at the same time as another.
usage_sentences: The gallery specializes in contemporary art.
Shakespeare and his contemporaries faced similar challenges.

2.meaning_en: Happy and at ease.
usage_sentences: She led a contented life in her small village.
The cat purred with a contented look on its face.
2.origin: From 'content', from Latin 'continere', meaning 'to hold together'.

3.meaning_en: The science that describes and maps the general features of the universe.
usage_sentences: Ancient cosmography often placed the Earth at the center of the universe.
His studies in cosmography involved mapping stars and galaxies.

3.meaning_en: The science of the origin and development of the universe.
usage_sentences: The Big Bang theory is a central concept in modern cosmology.
Cosmology explores fundamental questions about our existence.

3.meaning_en: Made in exact imitation of something valuable or important with the intention to deceive or defraud; a fraudulent imitation; to imitate fraudulently.
usage_sentences: The police seized a large quantity of counterfeit currency.
He was arrested for selling counterfeit luxury watches.
3.origin: From Old French 'contrefait', from 'contre-' (against) and 'faire' (to make).

3.meaning_en: A time of intense difficulty, trouble, or danger.
usage_sentences: The country is facing a severe economic crisis.
Her life reached a crisis point when she lost her job.

3.meaning_en: A principle or standard by which something may be judged or decided.
usage_sentences: Academic ability is not the sole criterion for admission.
What is the main criterion for making your decision?

3.meaning_en: A person who expresses an unfavorable opinion of something.
usage_sentences: The movie received harsh reviews from the critics.
He is a vocal critic of the government's policies.

3.meaning_en: A large number of people gathered together; to fill (a space) almost completely.
usage_sentences: A large crowd gathered to watch the parade.
Don't crowd around the accident site.
3.origin: From Old English 'crudan', meaning 'to press, push'.

3.meaning_en: Having a hard dry surface or coating.
usage_sentences: The old pot was crusted with dirt.
The snow became crusted over after a night of frost.

3.meaning_en: A style or method of cooking, especially as characteristic of a particular country, region.
usage_sentences: This restaurant is famous for its authentic French cuisine.
I love exploring the local cuisine when I travel.

3.meaning_en: Deserving blame.
usage_sentences: The court found him culpable for the accident.
Both parties were culpable to some extent.

3.meaning_en: The arts and other manifestations of human intellectual achievement regarded collectively.
usage_sentences: India has a rich and diverse culture.
Learning a new language can also help you understand its culture.

3.meaning_en: A regulation requiring people to remain indoors between specified hours, typically at night.
usage_sentences: The city was placed under a strict curfew after the riots.
My parents set a midnight curfew for me.

3.meaning_en: A strong desire to know or learn something.
usage_sentences: His curiosity led him to explore the old, abandoned house.
Children have a natural curiosity about the world.

3.meaning_en: A system of money in general use in a particular country.
usage_sentences: The local currency is the Rupee.
You will need to exchange your currency at the airport.
3.origin: From Latin 'currere', meaning 'to run, to flow'.

3.meaning_en: A solemn utterance intended to invoke a supernatural power to inflict harm or punishment on someone or something; to utter a curse.
usage_sentences: The witch put a curse on the royal family.
He muttered a curse under his breath.

3.meaning_en: A reckless person who enjoys doing dangerous things.
usage_sentences: The daredevil performed a stunt on a high wire without a net.
Only a daredevil would attempt such a dangerous jump.
3.origin: A compound of 'dare' and 'devil', suggesting someone who dares the devil.

3.meaning_en: A situation, typically one involving opposing parties, in which no progress can be made.
usage_sentences: The negotiations ended in a deadlock.
The committee reached a deadlock and could not pass the bill.
3.origin: A compound of 'dead' and 'lock', implying a lock that cannot be opened.

3.meaning_en: Lacking the power of hearing or having impaired hearing.
usage_sentences: He has been deaf since birth.
Many deaf people communicate using sign language.

3.meaning_en: A period of ten years.
usage_sentences: A lot has changed in the last decade.
The company celebrated a decade of success.

3.meaning_en: The process of converting a code into an understandable form; to convert into an understandable form.
usage_sentences: The spy was an expert in decoding secret messages.
Scientists are decoding the human genome.

3.meaning_en: The action of damaging the good reputation of someone; slander or libel.
usage_sentences: He sued the newspaper for defamation of character.
The article was full of lies and defamation.
3.origin: From Latin 'diffamare', meaning 'to spread evil report'.

3.meaning_en: Damage the good reputation of (someone); slander or libel.
usage_sentences: She claimed the article was intended to defame her.
It is illegal to defame someone with false accusations.
3.origin: From Latin 'diffamare', meaning 'to spread evil report'.

3.meaning_en: Resist an attack made on (someone or something); protect from harm or danger.
usage_sentences: The soldiers fought bravely to defend their country.
The lawyer's job is to defend the client in court.

3.meaning_en: Open resistance; bold disobedience.
usage_sentences: She acted in defiance of her parents' wishes.
Wearing casual clothes to the formal event was an act of defiance.

3.meaning_en: A lack or shortage.
usage_sentences: An iron deficiency can cause fatigue.
The report highlighted a deficiency in safety procedures.
3.origin: From Latin 'deficere', meaning 'to fail, to be wanting'.

3.meaning_en: A person sent or authorized to represent others; entrust (a task or responsibility) to another person.
usage_sentences: A delegate from each country attended the conference.
A good manager knows how to delegate tasks effectively.
3.origin: From Latin 'delegare', meaning 'to send on a commission'.

3.meaning_en: Long and careful consideration or discussion.
usage_sentences: After careful deliberation, they decided to sell the house.
The jury's deliberation lasted for two days.

3.meaning_en: Take away or alter the natural qualities of.
usage_sentences: Heating the protein will cause it to denature.
The extreme pH can denature the enzymes.

3.meaning_en: Show or represent by a drawing, painting, or other art form.
usage_sentences: The painting depicts a scene from Greek mythology.
The novel depicts the life of a soldier during the war.

3.meaning_en: Diminish in value over a period of time.
usage_sentences: A new car will depreciate in value as soon as you drive it.
The currency began to depreciate against the dollar.

3.meaning_en: A person whose immediate superior is a senior figure within an organization and who is empowered to act as a substitute for this superior.
usage_sentences: He served as the deputy director of the agency.
The sheriff appointed a new deputy.

3.meaning_en: A medical practitioner qualified to diagnose and treat skin disorders.
usage_sentences: She made an appointment with a dermatologist for her skin rash.
A dermatologist can help with conditions like acne and eczema.

3.meaning_en: Without the basic necessities of life; extremely poor.
usage_sentences: The war left thousands of people destitute.
Charities are working to help the destitute families.

3.meaning_en: A person, especially a police officer, whose occupation is to investigate and solve crimes.
usage_sentences: Sherlock Holmes is a famous fictional detective.
The detective gathered evidence at the crime scene.

3.meaning_en: Showing or having skill, especially with the hands.
usage_sentences: A watchmaker must be very dextrous.
He made a dextrous catch with one hand.
3.origin: From Latin 'dexter', meaning 'on the right side, skillful'.

3.meaning_en: Identify the nature of (an illness or other problem) by examination of the symptoms.
usage_sentences: The doctor was able to diagnose the illness quickly.
It can be difficult to diagnose the cause of the problem.

3.meaning_en: The identification of the nature of an illness or other problem by examination of the symptoms.
usage_sentences: The doctor's diagnosis was a severe case of the flu.
An early diagnosis can improve the chances of recovery.

3.meaning_en: Government by two independent authorities.
usage_sentences: The ancient Spartan government was a form of diearchy, with two kings.
The concept of a diearchy is rare in modern politics.

3.meaning_en: A ruler with total power over a country, typically one who has obtained control by force.
usage_sentences: The country suffered for years under the rule of a brutal dictator.
The people rose up against the dictator.
3.origin: From Latin 'dictare', meaning 'to say repeatedly, to prescribe'.

3.meaning_en: Spread or cause to spread over a wide area or among a large number of people; spread out over a large area; not concentrated.
usage_sentences: The heat from the radiator will diffuse throughout the room.
The use of diffuse light is better for reading.

3.meaning_en: A situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two or more alternatives, especially equally undesirable ones.
usage_sentences: She faced the dilemma of choosing between her career and her family.
This is a moral dilemma with no easy answer.

3.meaning_en: A sudden event, such as an accident or a natural catastrophe, that causes great damage or loss of life.
usage_sentences: The tsunami was a natural disaster of epic proportions.
The party was a complete disaster; everything went wrong.

3.meaning_en: Shockingly unacceptable.
usage_sentences: The team's performance in the final was disgraceful.
It is disgraceful that so many people are homeless.

3.meaning_en: Give (someone or oneself) a different appearance in order to conceal one's identity; a means of altering one's appearance to conceal one's identity.
usage_sentences: The spy used a clever disguise to avoid being recognized.
She tried to disguise her voice on the phone.
3.origin: From Old French 'desguisier', meaning 'to change one's usual costume'.

3.meaning_en: Break up into small parts, typically as the result of impact or decay.
usage_sentences: The ancient manuscript began to disintegrate when touched.
The spaceship will disintegrate upon re-entry into the atmosphere.

3.meaning_en: Interrupt (an event) by causing a disturbance or problem.
usage_sentences: A protestor tried to disrupt the speaker's presentation.
Bad weather could disrupt our travel plans.

3.meaning_en: The state of being diverse; variety.
usage_sentences: The country is known for its cultural diversity.
We need to encourage diversity in the workplace.

3.meaning_en: The country that a person treats as their permanent home.
usage_sentences: You must declare your country of domicile for tax purposes.
Although he traveled often, his official domicile was in France.

3.meaning_en: Sovereignty; control.
usage_sentences: The king had dominion over a vast territory.
Man seeks to have dominion over nature.

3.meaning_en: (of an animal) having normal physical functions suspended or slowed down for a period of time; in or as if in a deep sleep.
usage_sentences: The volcano has been dormant for many years.
Many seeds remain dormant until the spring.

4.meaning_en: A large bedroom for a number of people in a school or institution.
usage_sentences: College students often live in a dormitory during their first year.
The old boarding school had long, cold dormitories.

4.meaning_en: Strengthen one's commitment to a particular strategy or course of action, typically one that is potentially risky.
usage_sentences: Instead of admitting his mistake, the politician decided to double down on his statement.
The company is doubling down on its investment in renewable energy.
4.origin: Derived from the card game blackjack, where a player doubles their bet.

4.meaning_en: A heavy fall of rain.
usage_sentences: We got caught in a sudden downpour without an umbrella.
The downpour flooded the streets in just a few minutes.
4.origin: A compound of the words 'down' and 'pour'.

4.meaning_en: A current of cool air in a room or other confined space.
usage_sentences: Please close the door; there's a terrible draught in here.
She felt a cold draught on her neck.
4.origin: From Old English 'drag', related to the verb 'draw'.

4.meaning_en: (of a metal) able to be drawn out into a thin wire; able to be deformed without losing toughness.
usage_sentences: Gold is a highly ductile metal, which allows it to be made into fine jewelry.
Ductile materials can be stretched into wires without breaking.
4.origin: From Latin 'ductilis', from 'ducere' (to lead, to draw).

4.meaning_en: Temporarily unable or unwilling to speak; (informal) stupid.
usage_sentences: He was struck dumb with amazement at the news.
She stood there dumb, unable to utter a single word.
4.origin: From Old English 'dumb', of Germanic origin.

4.meaning_en: Able to withstand wear, pressure, or damage; hard-wearing.
usage_sentences: These hiking boots are made from durable leather.
They are looking for a durable solution to the infrastructure problem.

4.meaning_en: A person, animal, or plant much below the usual height; cause to seem small or insignificant in comparison; below the usual height.
usage_sentences: The giant skyscraper seemed to dwarf all the surrounding buildings.
In the fairy tale, the seven dwarfs helped Snow White.
4.origin: From Old English 'dweorg', of Germanic origin.

4.meaning_en: A line of hereditary rulers of a country.
usage_sentences: The Ming dynasty ruled China for over 270 years.
His family has created a powerful business dynasty in the tech industry.

4.meaning_en: A sound caused by the reflection of sound waves; to repeat.
usage_sentences: His shout produced a clear echo from the other side of the valley.
The large hall was so empty that her footsteps had an echo.
4.origin: From Greek 'ēkhō', the name of a nymph in mythology.

4.meaning_en: A person who studies Ecology/An expert in or student of the branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.
usage_sentences: The ecologist studied the impact of pollution on the local river.
Ecologists are warning about the long-term effects of deforestation.
4.origin: From 'ecology', which comes from Greek 'oikos' (house) and '-logia' (study).

4.meaning_en: Giving good value or return in relation to the money, time, or effort expended.
usage_sentences: It's more economical to buy groceries in bulk.
She drives a small, economical car to save on fuel.

4.meaning_en: Fit to be eaten.
usage_sentences: Not all wild mushrooms are edible; some are highly poisonous.
The wedding cake was decorated with beautiful edible flowers.

4.meaning_en: (of a man) having or showing characteristics regarded as typical of a woman; unmanly.
usage_sentences: He was teased at school for his effeminate voice.
The actor was often cast in roles portraying effeminate characters.

4.meaning_en: A person who is self-centered.
usage_sentences: An egoist primarily thinks of their own needs and desires.
His egoist attitude made it difficult for him to maintain friendships.

4.meaning_en: A person who is excessively conceited or self-absorbed; a self-centered person.
usage_sentences: The egotist bored everyone by constantly talking about his achievements.
It's hard to have a conversation with an egotist because they only talk about themselves.

4.meaning_en: All the people in a country or area who are entitled to vote in an election.
usage_sentences: The candidate tried to appeal to a broad section of the electorate.
The government must be responsive to the needs of the electorate.

4.meaning_en: A poem, typically a lament for the dead.
usage_sentences: The poet wrote a moving elegy for his departed friend.
Gray's 'Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard' is a famous example.

4.meaning_en: Make (something) clear; explain.
usage_sentences: Could you please elucidate your theory for us?
The professor used a diagram to elucidate the complex process.

4.meaning_en: Fix (an object) firmly and deeply in a surrounding mass.
usage_sentences: The ancient fossil was embedded in the rock.
You can embed a YouTube video directly into your webpage.
4.origin: From the prefix 'em-' (in) and the word 'bed'.

4.meaning_en: A person who leaves their own country in order to settle permanently in another.
usage_sentences: He was an emigrant from Ireland who moved to the United States in the 19th century.
The museum tells the stories of the many emigrants who built the nation.

4.meaning_en: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another.
usage_sentences: A good doctor must have empathy for their patients.
She felt a great deal of empathy for the victims of the disaster.

4.meaning_en: A person or organization that employs people.
usage_sentences: Her employer praised her for her excellent work.
The company is one of the largest employers in the state.
4.origin: From the verb 'employ', which comes from Old French 'employer'.

4.meaning_en: A book or set of books giving information on many subjects or on many aspects of one subject and typically arranged alphabetically.
usage_sentences: Before the internet, people would look up facts in an encyclopedia.
Wikipedia is a popular online encyclopedia.

4.meaning_en: Try hard to do or achieve something; an attempt to achieve a goal.
usage_sentences: We must always endeavor to do our best.
His latest artistic endeavor is a series of sculptures.
4.origin: From Old French 'en devoir', meaning 'in duty'.

4.meaning_en: (of a disease or condition) regularly found among particular people or in a certain area; an endemic plant or animal.
usage_sentences: Malaria is endemic in many tropical countries.
This particular species of bird is endemic to the island.

4.meaning_en: (of a natural force) sweep over (something) so as to surround or cover it completely.
usage_sentences: The flames quickly engulfed the entire building.
A feeling of despair threatened to engulf him.
4.origin: From the prefix 'en-' (in) and the word 'gulf'.

4.meaning_en: Preserve (a right, tradition, or idea) in a form that ensures it will be protected and respected.
usage_sentences: The right to free speech is enshrined in the constitution.
The memory of the national hero is enshrined in a grand monument.
4.origin: From the prefix 'en-' (in) and the word 'shrine'.

4.meaning_en: A person who studies or is an expert in the branch of zoology concerned with insects.
usage_sentences: The entomologist identified the new species of butterfly.
An entomologist was consulted to deal with the locust plague.

4.meaning_en: Arousing or likely to arouse envy.
usage_sentences: She has an enviable ability to learn new languages quickly.
He is in the enviable position of having to choose between two excellent job offers.
4.origin: From the word 'envy', derived from Old French 'envie'.

4.meaning_en: A long poem, typically one derived from ancient oral tradition; heroic or grand in scale or character.
usage_sentences: Homer's 'The Odyssey' is a classic Greek epic.
The movie was an epic saga spanning several generations.

4.meaning_en: A widespread occurrence of an infectious disease in a community at a particular time; of the nature of an epidemic.
usage_sentences: Health officials worked tirelessly to contain the flu epidemic.
The city was in the grip of a cholera epidemic.

4.meaning_en: A person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type.
usage_sentences: With his courage and kindness, he was the epitome of a true hero.
This luxury car is the epitome of automotive engineering.

4.meaning_en: An imaginary line drawn around the earth equally distant from both poles, dividing the earth into northern and southern hemispheres.
usage_sentences: Countries located on the equator experience a hot climate year-round.
The ship crossed the equator during its long voyage.
4.origin: From late Latin 'aequator', in the phrase 'circulus aequator diei et noctis' (circle equalizing day and night).

4.meaning_en: A state in which opposing forces or influences are balanced.
usage_sentences: The tightrope walker struggled to maintain his equilibrium.
The market reached a state of equilibrium where supply and demand were equal.

4.meaning_en: The time or date (twice each year) at which the sun crosses the celestial equator, when day and night are of equal length.
usage_sentences: The spring equinox marks the beginning of spring in the Northern Hemisphere.
During the equinox, day and night are of approximately equal length.

4.meaning_en: Destroy completely; put an end to.
usage_sentences: Global efforts have been made to eradicate diseases like polio.
We must work together to eradicate poverty and hunger.

4.meaning_en: Excessive desire to work; workaholism.
usage_sentences: His ergomania was negatively impacting his health and family life.
Suffering from ergomania, he never took a day off.

4.meaning_en: A person who loves to work.
usage_sentences: As a true ergophile, he was happiest when busy with a challenging project.
The company values ergophiles who show great dedication.

4.meaning_en: (Noun) - Respect and admiration, typically for a person. (Verb) - Respect and admire.
usage_sentences: She is held in high esteem by all of her colleagues.
It is important to have good self-esteem.
4.origin: From Old French 'estimer', from Latin 'aestimare' (to value, appraise).

4.meaning_en: Lasting or existing forever; without end.
usage_sentences: They swore their eternal love for one another.
The flame is a symbol of the eternal spirit of the nation.

4.meaning_en: Infinite or unending time.
usage_sentences: It felt like an eternity while we waited for the test results.
Some philosophies believe the soul lives on for all eternity.

4.meaning_en: Moral principles that govern a person's behavior or the conducting of an activity.
usage_sentences: Doctors are bound by a strict code of professional ethics.
The company was criticized for its poor business ethics.

4.meaning_en: The study of the characteristics of various peoples and the differences and relationships between them.
usage_sentences: The professor of ethnology compared the marriage customs of different cultures.
Ethnology helps us understand the development of human societies.

4.meaning_en: The study of the origin of words and the way in which their meanings have changed throughout history.
4.meaning_hi: व्युत्पत्ति विज्ञान/शब्दों की उत्पत्ति का अध्ययन
usage_sentences: The etymology of the word 'companion' relates to sharing bread with someone.
He has a keen interest in the etymology of English words.

4.meaning_en: Remove (someone) from a place of danger to a safer place.
usage_sentences: Residents were ordered to evacuate their homes before the hurricane hit.
The building was evacuated after a bomb threat was received.

4.meaning_en: Develop gradually, especially from a simple to a more complex form.
usage_sentences: Scientists believe that modern humans evolved from earlier primates.
The company's marketing strategy has evolved over the years.

4.meaning_en: Represent (something) as being larger, better, or worse than it really is.
usage_sentences: He tends to exaggerate the difficulty of his job.
Don't exaggerate; the fish you caught wasn't that big!

4.meaning_en: A person who is taking an examination.
usage_sentences: The examinee must bring a photo ID to the test center.
Examinees were instructed to put their pens down when the time was up.
4.origin: From the verb 'examine', derived from Latin 'examinare'.

4.meaning_en: A feeling of excitement, happiness, or elation.
usage_sentences: She felt a sense of exhilaration as she crossed the finish line.
The exhilarating ride on the roller coaster left them screaming with joy.

5.meaning_en: A poll of voters taken immediately after they have exited the polling stations.
usage_sentences: The initial exit polls suggest a close election.
News channels often broadcast the results of their exit polls as soon as voting ends.

5.meaning_en: An area of wide extent of something, typically land, sea, or sky.
usage_sentences: The Sahara is a vast expanse of desert.
He gazed out at the endless expanse of the Pacific Ocean.

5.meaning_en: A journey or voyage undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose, especially that of exploration, research, or war.
usage_sentences: He joined a scientific expedition to the Amazon rainforest.
The expedition to climb Mount Everest was a great success.

5.meaning_en: Force (someone) to leave a place, organization, or country.
usage_sentences: The student was expelled from school for repeated misbehavior.
The country decided to expel the foreign diplomat.

5.meaning_en: (Of a document, authorization, or agreement) come to the end of the period of validity.
usage_sentences: My passport is going to expire next month.
The special offer will expire at midnight tonight.

5.meaning_en: Put out (a fire or light).
usage_sentences: Firefighters worked for hours to extinguish the forest fire.
Please extinguish all cigarettes before entering the building.

5.meaning_en: The practice of obtaining something, especially money, through force or threats.
usage_sentences: The shopkeeper was a victim of extortion by a local gang.
He was arrested and charged with extortion.
5.origin: From late Latin 'extortio(n-)', from 'extorquere' (to wrench out).

5.meaning_en: An outgoing, overtly expressive person.
usage_sentences: As an extrovert, she thrives in social situations and loves meeting new people.
His extrovert personality makes him a very effective salesperson.
5.origin: From German 'Extrovert', from Latin 'extra-' (outside) and 'vertere' (to turn).

5.meaning_en: An exact copy, especially of written or printed material.
usage_sentences: The museum displayed a high-quality facsimile of the original document.
You can send a facsimile of the contract to our office.

5.meaning_en: A small, organized, dissenting group within a larger one, especially in politics.
usage_sentences: The political party was deeply divided by warring factions.
A small faction of the shareholders opposed the merger.

5.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Not genuine or real; counterfeit. (Noun) - A thing that is not genuine; a forgery or sham. (Verb) - Falsify; forge.
usage_sentences: The police warned about fake currency notes in circulation.
He was caught trying to use a fake ID to enter the club.
5.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly from thieves' slang.

5.meaning_en: Capable of making mistakes or being erroneous.
usage_sentences: All human beings are fallible and can make mistakes.
Memory is fallible, so it's good to write things down.

5.meaning_en: The state of being untrue; lack of correspondence to fact or reality.
usage_sentences: The witness was accused of telling a deliberate falsehood in court.
He spread malicious falsehoods about his rival.

5.meaning_en: Extreme scarcity of food.
usage_sentences: A prolonged drought led to a severe famine in the region.
Millions of people died during the great famine of the 19th century.

5.meaning_en: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
usage_sentences: He is very fastidious about keeping his house clean.
The fastidious editor checked every single comma in the manuscript.

5.meaning_en: Causing death.
usage_sentences: The driver sustained fatal injuries in the accident.
Delaying the decision could have a fatal impact on the project.

5.meaning_en: The development of events beyond a person's control, regarded as predetermined by a supernatural power.
usage_sentences: He felt that it was his fate to become a doctor.
They believed their meeting was a matter of fate.
5.origin: From Latin 'fatum', meaning 'that which has been spoken'.

5.meaning_en: The animals of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
usage_sentences: The book documents the diverse flora and fauna of the Amazon rainforest.
Australia is known for its unique and unusual fauna.
5.origin: From 'Fauna', the name of a Roman goddess of earth and fertility.

5.meaning_en: Possible and practical to do easily or conveniently.
usage_sentences: We need to find a feasible solution to this problem.
Building a new airport is not financially feasible at the moment.

5.meaning_en: Congratulate (someone).
usage_sentences: The principal will felicitate the top-ranking students at the ceremony.
We would like to felicitate you on your remarkable achievement.

5.meaning_en: Present participle of felicitate (congratulating).
usage_sentences: The crowd was busy felicitating the winning team.
He sent a card felicitating the new parents.

5.meaning_en: An advocate of women's rights on the grounds of political, social, and economic equality to men.
usage_sentences: She is a prominent feminist who campaigns for gender equality.
The feminist movement has brought about significant social changes.

5.meaning_en: Relating to a festival or feast; festive.
usage_sentences: The town was decorated in a festal manner for the annual celebration.
A festal mood pervaded the entire city during the holidays.

5.meaning_en: Literature in the form of prose, especially novels and short stories, that describes imaginary events and people.
usage_sentences: She enjoys reading historical fiction.
The story is a work of fiction and any resemblance to real people is coincidental.

5.meaning_en: Not real or true, being imaginary or having been fabricated.
usage_sentences: All the characters in the novel are fictitious.
He gave a fictitious name to the police officer.
5.origin: From late Latin 'ficticius', from 'fingere' (to form, contrive).

5.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Solid, strong, and unyielding. (Noun) - A business partnership or company. (Verb) - Make or become firm.
usage_sentences: You need a firm mattress for good back support.
He works for a major law firm in the city.

5.meaning_en: A mark, blemish, or other imperfection which mars a substance or surface.
usage_sentences: There was a small flaw in the diamond that reduced its value.
Despite his many talents, his main flaw is arrogance.

5.meaning_en: Capable of bending easily without breaking.
usage_sentences: Gymnasts and dancers need to be extremely flexible.
My work hours are flexible, so I can start and finish early.

5.meaning_en: (Noun) - A number of birds of one kind feeding, resting, or traveling together. (Verb) - Congregate or flock together.
usage_sentences: A flock of sheep was grazing in the field.
Tourists flock to the city every summer to see the sights.

5.meaning_en: The plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
usage_sentences: The book provides a detailed guide to the local flora.
Scientists are studying the unique flora of the island.
5.origin: From 'Flora', the name of the Roman goddess of flowers.

5.meaning_en: A person who sells flowers and ornamental plants.
usage_sentences: I ordered a beautiful bouquet from the local florist.
She decided to become a florist because of her love for flowers.

5.meaning_en: The action or process of flowing or flowing out.
usage_sentences: The country's political situation is currently in a state of flux.
The technology industry is in constant flux, with new innovations every day.

5.meaning_en: The destruction of a fetus.
usage_sentences: Female foeticide is a major social issue in some parts of the world.
Strict laws have been enacted to prevent foeticide.

5.meaning_en: (Noun) - People in general. (Adjective) - Of or relating to the traditional art or culture of a community or nation.
usage_sentences: The festival featured traditional folk music and dancing.
The old folks in the village have many stories to tell.
5.origin: From Old English 'folc', of Germanic origin.

5.meaning_en: A traditional story passed down orally.
usage_sentences: Every culture has its own unique collection of folktales.
The children gathered around to listen to an old folktale.

5.meaning_en: Go or come after (a person or thing proceeding ahead); move or travel behind.
usage_sentences: The little ducklings follow their mother everywhere she goes.
Please follow the instructions carefully to assemble the furniture.
5.origin: From Old English 'folgian', of Germanic origin.

5.meaning_en: Relating to or denoting the application of scientific methods and techniques to the investigation of crime.
usage_sentences: The forensic team collected fingerprints and DNA evidence from the crime scene.
Forensic science played a crucial role in solving the case.
5.origin: From Latin 'forensis' (of the forum, public), from 'forum'.

5.meaning_en: The remains or impression of a prehistoric plant or animal embedded in rock and preserved in petrified form.
usage_sentences: Paleontologists discovered the fossil of a new dinosaur species.
Fossil fuels like coal and oil are formed from ancient organic matter.

5.meaning_en: Easily broken or damaged; delicate.
usage_sentences: Please handle this fragile antique vase with extreme care.
The peace agreement between the two countries is still very fragile.

5.meaning_en: The killing of one's brother or sister.
usage_sentences: The story of Cain and Abel is a biblical tale of fratricide.
The civil war was a tragedy of fratricide, pitting brother against brother.

5.meaning_en: Wrongful or criminal deception intended to result in financial or personal gain.
usage_sentences: He was found guilty of committing tax fraud.
The company was involved in a massive accounting fraud.

5.meaning_en: The feeling of being upset or annoyed as a result of being unable to change or achieve something.
usage_sentences: She screamed out in frustration when her computer crashed again.
His inability to solve the puzzle was a source of great frustration.

5.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who has escaped from captivity or is in hiding, especially to avoid arrest or prosecution. (Adjective) - Having escaped or run away.
usage_sentences: The police launched a massive manhunt for the fugitive.
He lived as a fugitive for ten years before being captured.

5.meaning_en: A person or event organized for the purpose of raising money for a cause or charity.
usage_sentences: The school organized a fundraiser to build a new library.
She is an experienced fundraiser for several non-profit organizations.

5.meaning_en: A member of a large group of eukaryotic organisms that includes microorganisms (such as yeasts and molds) as well as the more familiar mushrooms and toadstools.
usage_sentences: Mushrooms and molds are both types of fungus.
The damp conditions in the basement led to the growth of fungus on the walls.

5.meaning_en: The thick coat of soft hair on the body of a mammal.
usage_sentences: The cat has thick, soft fur that is pleasant to touch.
The use of animal fur in fashion is a controversial topic.

5.meaning_en: (Noun) - Excessive concern over something unimportant. (Verb) - Show unnecessary or excessive concern about something.
usage_sentences: Don't make such a fuss over a little spilled milk.
There was a lot of fuss and excitement when the movie star arrived.

5.meaning_en: (Of a person or their behavior) brave; heroic.
usage_sentences: The gallant soldier was awarded a medal for his bravery.
He made a gallant effort to rescue the people from the burning building.
5.origin: From Old French 'galant', from 'galer' (to rejoice, make merry).

5.meaning_en: An award bestowed for gallant or heroic acts.
usage_sentences: He received the nation's highest gallantry award for his actions in the war.
Several soldiers were presented with gallantry awards at the ceremony.

5.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Affecting or concerning all or most people, places, or things; widespread. (Noun) - A commander of an army, or an army officer of very high rank.
usage_sentences: The general consensus is that the new policy will be beneficial.
He was promoted to the rank of General in the army.

6.meaning_en: The origin or mode of formation of something.
usage_sentences: The book describes the genesis of the American Revolution.
The project had its genesis in a conversation between two friends.

6.meaning_en: The study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.
usage_sentences: She is a leading researcher in the field of human genetics.
Advances in genetics have led to new treatments for many diseases.
6.origin: From 'gene', which comes from Greek 'genos' (race, kind).

6.meaning_en: Exceptional intellectual or creative power or other natural ability.
usage_sentences: Leonardo da Vinci was a true genius, excelling in both art and science.
She has a genius for solving complex mathematical problems.
6.origin: From Latin 'genius', originally 'attendant spirit present from one's birth'.

6.meaning_en: The deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular ethnic group or nation.
usage_sentences: The international community has a duty to prevent genocide.
He was put on trial for committing acts of genocide.

6.meaning_en: Truly what something is said to be; authentic.
usage_sentences: This is a genuine leather handbag, not a cheap imitation.
He showed genuine remorse for his actions.

6.meaning_en: The study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere, and of human activity as it affects and is affected by these.
usage_sentences: In geography class, we learned about the world's major rivers and mountains.
The geography of the region, with its mountains and deserts, makes travel difficult.

6.meaning_en: The science that deals with the earth's physical structure and substance, its history, and the processes which act on it.
usage_sentences: He is studying geology at the university to become a geoscientist.
The geology of the area is rich in mineral deposits.

6.meaning_en: Plural of geologist (a scientist who studies geology).
usage_sentences: Geologists were sent to study the site after the earthquake.
The team of geologists discovered a large deposit of iron ore.

6.meaning_en: The scientific study of old age, the process of aging, and the particular problems of old people.
usage_sentences: Research in gerontology aims to improve the quality of life for the elderly.
She is a professor of gerontology at the medical university.

6.meaning_en: (Noun) - A movement of part of the body, especially a hand or the head, to express an idea or meaning. (Verb) - Move one's hand or head to express an idea or feeling.
usage_sentences: He made a welcoming gesture with his hands.
In many cultures, a nod is a common gesture of agreement.
6.origin: From medieval Latin 'gestura', from 'gerere' (to bear, carry).

6.meaning_en: A slowly moving mass or river of ice formed by the accumulation and compaction of snow on mountains or near the poles.
usage_sentences: Climate change is causing glaciers around the world to melt at an alarming rate.
The massive glacier carved out the valley thousands of years ago.

6.meaning_en: An alphabetical list of terms or words found in or relating to a specific subject, text, or dialect, with explanations.
usage_sentences: If you don't understand a technical term in this book, look it up in the glossary.
The textbook includes a glossary of important scientific terms.
6.origin: From late Latin 'glossarium', from Greek 'glōssa' (tongue, language).

6.meaning_en: An excessively greedy eater.
usage_sentences: He ate the entire cake by himself; he's such a glutton!
He is a glutton for punishment, always taking on the most difficult tasks.

6.meaning_en: (Noun) - transplant of living tissue. (Verb) - Insert or fix (a shoot or twig) as a graft.
usage_sentences: The doctor performed a skin graft to help the burn victim heal.
The politician was accused of accepting a graft in exchange for favors.
6.origin: From Old French 'grafe', from Greek 'graphein' (to write), via the sense of a stylus-shaped shoot.

6.meaning_en: The process of graft (insert or fix (a shoot or twig) as a graft).
usage_sentences: Grafting is a common horticultural technique to join two plants together.
The surgeon was an expert in bone grafting procedures.

6.meaning_en: A storehouse for grain or animal feed.
usage_sentences: The farmer stored the freshly harvested wheat in the granary.
Ancient Rome had large public granaries to ensure a stable food supply.

6.meaning_en: The study of handwriting and especially its use in inferring character and aptitudes.
usage_sentences: Some companies use graphology to analyze job applicants' personalities.
She hired a graphology expert to verify the signature on the document.

6.meaning_en: A glass building in which plants are grown that need protection from cold weather.
usage_sentences: They grow tomatoes and exotic flowers in their greenhouse all winter.
A greenhouse works by trapping the sun's heat.

6.meaning_en: (Verb) - Reduce (something) to small particles or powder by crushing it. (Noun) - Hard, laborious work.
usage_sentences: You need to grind the coffee beans to make fresh coffee.
The daily grind of working two jobs was exhausting.
6.origin: From Old English 'grindan', of Germanic origin.

6.meaning_en: A room or building equipped for gymnastics, games, and other physical exercise.
usage_sentences: He goes to the gym every morning before work.
The school's new gymnasium has a swimming pool and a basketball court.
6.origin: From Greek 'gumnasion', from 'gumnos' (naked), as athletes trained unclothed.

6.meaning_en: A physician specializing in gynecology, the branch of medicine dealing with disorders of the female reproductive system.
usage_sentences: It is recommended to have a regular check-up with a gynecologist.
She consulted a gynecologist about her health concerns.
6.origin: From 'gynecology', which is from Greek 'gunē' (woman) and '-logia' (study).

6.meaning_en: The branch of medicine concerned with the study of the cause, prognosis, treatment, and prevention of diseases related to blood.
usage_sentences: The patient was referred to the haematology department for blood tests.
Haematology deals with diseases like anemia and leukemia.

6.meaning_en: An experience involving the apparent perception of something not present.
usage_sentences: The high fever caused the patient to have vivid hallucinations.
Certain drugs can induce powerful hallucinations.
6.origin: From Latin 'hallucinatio(n-)', from 'hallucinari' (to wander in mind).

6.meaning_en: A drug that causes hallucinations.
usage_sentences: LSD is a well-known synthetic hallucinogen.
The use of hallucinogens can have long-lasting psychological effects.

6.meaning_en: Creative work with one's hands; design and production of useful and decorative objects by hand.
usage_sentences: The local market is famous for its beautiful handicrafts.
She sells her handmade jewelry and other handicrafts online.

6.meaning_en: Subject to aggressive pressure or intimidation.
usage_sentences: It is against the law to harass someone in the workplace.
She reported her neighbor to the police for constantly harassing her.
6.origin: From Old French 'harer', meaning 'to set a dog on'.

6.meaning_en: Cruel or severe; unkind.
usage_sentences: The dictator was known for his harsh treatment of political opponents.
Living conditions in the refugee camp were very harsh.
6.origin: Of Middle German origin, related to 'hairy'.

6.meaning_en: In a hearty manner; sincerely; enthusiastically.
usage_sentences: They all laughed heartily at his joke.
After the long hike, they ate heartily.
6.origin: From the word 'hearty', derived from Old English 'heorte' (heart).

6.meaning_en: Extremely distressing; agonizing.
usage_sentences: The movie told the heart-wrenching story of a family torn apart by war.
It was a heart-wrenching decision to put their old dog to sleep.

6.meaning_en: (Verb) - Pay attention to; take notice of. (Noun) - Careful attention.
usage_sentences: You should heed the warnings about the approaching storm.
He failed to heed his lawyer's advice and ended up in trouble.
6.origin: From Old English 'hēdan', of Germanic origin.

6.meaning_en: A person legally entitled to the property or rank of another on that person's death.
usage_sentences: As the eldest son, he is the heir to the family fortune.
The prince is the heir to the throne.

6.meaning_en: A plane figure with seven straight sides and seven angles.
usage_sentences: The teacher asked the students to identify the heptagon among the shapes.
A heptagon has seven vertices and seven angles.

6.meaning_en: An animal that feeds on plants.
usage_sentences: Cows, elephants, and deer are examples of herbivores.
The large dinosaur was a herbivore, despite its size.

6.meaning_en: (Noun) - A large group of animals, especially hoofed mammals, that live together or are kept together as livestock. (Verb) - Move in a herd.
usage_sentences: A herd of cattle was grazing peacefully in the pasture.
The tour guide spotted a large herd of elephants near the waterhole.
6.origin: From Old English 'heord', of Germanic origin.

6.meaning_en: A person living in solitude as a religious discipline.
usage_sentences: The hermit lived a simple life in a remote cabin in the woods.
He chose to become a hermit to escape the pressures of modern society.

6.meaning_en: Pause before saying or doing something, especially through uncertainty or reluctance.
usage_sentences: Don't hesitate to ask for help if you need it.
She hesitated for a moment before answering the difficult question.
6.origin: From Latin 'haesitare', from 'haerere' (to stick, hold fast).

6.meaning_en: Diverse in character or content.
usage_sentences: New York City has a very heterogeneous population.
The student body at the university is culturally heterogeneous.

6.meaning_en: A plane figure with six straight sides and six angles.
usage_sentences: A honeycomb is made up of many small hexagonal cells.
A standard nut or bolt head is often in the shape of a hexagon.

6.meaning_en: (Of an animal) spend the winter in a dormant state.
usage_sentences: Bears find a den to hibernate in during the cold winter months.
Some species of frogs and turtles also hibernate.

6.meaning_en: The condition or period of an animal or plant hibernating.
usage_sentences: The bear emerged from its long winter hibernation.
Hibernation allows animals to conserve energy when food is scarce.

6.meaning_en: Unlawfully seize (an aircraft, vehicle, or ship) in transit and force it to go to a different destination or use it for one's own purposes.
usage_sentences: The terrorists attempted to hijack the airplane.
His truck was hijacked and the cargo was stolen.
6.origin: From US slang, of uncertain origin, possibly from 'highwayman' + 'jacker'.

6.meaning_en: (Verb) - Make a sharp sibilant sound as of the letter s. (Noun) - A sibilant sound.
usage_sentences: The snake reared its head and began to hiss.
The angry cat arched its back and let out a loud hiss.

6.meaning_en: A beehive, especially one of made by humans.
usage_sentences: The beekeeper collected honey from the hive.
The office was a hive of activity before the deadline.

6.meaning_en: The killing of one human being by another.
usage_sentences: The police are investigating the death as a possible homicide.
He was charged with vehicular homicide after the drunk-driving accident.

6.meaning_en: Of the same kind; alike.
usage_sentences: The population of the small village was remarkably homogeneous.
Stir the mixture until it becomes a homogeneous liquid.

6.meaning_en: Each of two or more words having the same spelling or pronunciation but different meanings and origins.
usage_sentences: The words 'bat' (animal) and 'bat' (sports equipment) are homonyms.
Understanding homonyms is an important part of learning English.

6.meaning_en: A payment given for professional services that are rendered nominally without charge.
usage_sentences: The guest lecturer received a small honorarium for his talk.
The organization paid him an honorarium to cover his travel expenses.

6.meaning_en: (Of an office or position) held or given as an honor, without payment for services.
usage_sentences: The university awarded him an honorary doctorate degree.
She serves as the honorary chairperson of the charity.

6.meaning_en: Worthy of honor; respected.
usage_sentences: He is an honourable man who always keeps his promises.
It was the honourable thing to do, even though it was difficult.
6.origin: From Old French 'honorable', from Latin 'honorabilis' (worthy of honor).

6.meaning_en: The line at which the earth's surface and the sky appear to meet.
usage_sentences: We watched the beautiful sunset as the sun sank below the horizon.
New scientific discoveries are always on the horizon.

7.meaning_en: Friendly and welcoming to strangers or guests.
usage_sentences: The local people were very hospitable and invited us into their homes for dinner.
The hotel is known for its hospitable atmosphere and excellent service.

7.meaning_en: The friendly and generous reception and entertainment of guests, visitors, or strangers.
usage_sentences: They thanked their hosts for their warm hospitality during their stay.
The tourism industry relies on providing excellent hospitality.

7.meaning_en: A woman who receives or entertains guests.
usage_sentences: The hostess greeted each guest at the door with a warm smile.
She was a wonderful hostess, making sure everyone had enough to eat and drink.
7.origin: From Old French 'hostesse', from Latin 'hospes' (guest, host).

7.meaning_en: The organic component of soil, formed by the decomposition of leaves and other plant material by soil microorganisms.
usage_sentences: Rich in humus, this soil is perfect for growing vegetables.
Adding compost to the garden increases the humus content of the soil.

7.meaning_en: A storm with a violent wind, in particular a tropical cyclone in the Caribbean.
usage_sentences: The coastal city was devastated by the powerful hurricane.
Forecasters warned residents to evacuate before the hurricane made landfall.
7.origin: From Spanish 'huracán', from a Taino (Caribbean) word.

7.meaning_en: Done in a hurry; rushed.
usage_sentences: She ate a hurried breakfast before running out the door.
The decision was a hurried one, and they later regretted it.
7.origin: From the verb 'hurry', of uncertain origin.

7.meaning_en: In a hurried manner; rapidly; quickly.
usage_sentences: He hurriedly packed his bags and left the hotel.
The note was written hurriedly and was difficult to read.

7.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of water, especially as a symptom of rabies in humans.
usage_sentences: A key symptom of advanced rabies is hydrophobia, making it difficult for the patient to swallow.
His hydrophobia was so severe that he couldn't even take a shower.

7.meaning_en: The practice of claiming to have moral standards or beliefs to which one's own behavior does not conform; pretense.
usage_sentences: It's sheer hypocrisy for him to talk about saving money when he spends so much.
She accused the politician of hypocrisy for breaking his campaign promises.
7.origin: From Greek 'hupokrisis', meaning 'acting of a theatrical part'.

7.meaning_en: A person who indulges in hypocrisy.
usage_sentences: He's a hypocrite; he tells us to be eco-friendly but drives a gas-guzzling car.
Don't be a hypocrite; practice what you preach.

7.meaning_en: A supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.
usage_sentences: The scientist formulated a hypothesis to explain the strange results.
Further experiments are needed to test this hypothesis.

7.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Perfectly suitable; most appropriate. (Noun) - A standard of perfection; a principle to be aimed at.
usage_sentences: This sunny weather is ideal for a picnic in the park.
She strives to live up to her high moral ideals.

7.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Not active or in use. (Verb) - Spend time doing nothing; be lazy.
usage_sentences: The old factory has been lying idle for years.
He spent the afternoon just idling around the house.

7.meaning_en: An image or representation of a god used as an object of worship.
usage_sentences: The ancient temple contained a large golden idol.
He is a pop idol with millions of teenage fans.

7.meaning_en: A dome-shaped house built of blocks of solid snow, traditionally used by Eskimos.
usage_sentences: The hunter built a temporary igloo for shelter during the blizzard.
Inside the igloo, it was surprisingly warm compared to the outside.

7.meaning_en: Refuse to take notice of or acknowledge; disregard intentionally.
usage_sentences: He chose to ignore the warning signs and continued on his path.
If you ignore the problem, it will only get worse.
7.origin: From Latin 'ignorare', meaning 'not to know, to disregard'.

7.meaning_en: Poor physical or mental condition; sickness.
usage_sentences: He had to retire early due to persistent ill health.
A poor diet and lack of exercise can lead to ill health.

7.meaning_en: Not clear enough to be read.
usage_sentences: The doctor's handwriting was completely illegible.
The old document was faded and largely illegible.

7.meaning_en: Forbidden by law, rules, or custom.
usage_sentences: He was arrested for selling illicit drugs.
The company was investigated for illicit financial activities.

7.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Unable to read or write. (Noun) - A person who is unable to read or write.
usage_sentences: The organization works to help illiterate adults learn to read.
In the 19th century, a large portion of the population was illiterate.

7.meaning_en: Light up.
usage_sentences: The fireworks will illuminate the night sky.
The professor's lecture helped to illuminate a difficult topic.

7.meaning_en: A picture illustrating a book, newspaper, etc.
usage_sentences: The children's book was filled with colorful illustrations.
A clear illustration can help explain a complex idea.
7.origin: From Latin 'illustrare', meaning 'to light up, explain'.

7.meaning_en: Existing only in the imagination; not real.
usage_sentences: As a child, she had an imaginary friend named Leo.
Dragons and unicorns are imaginary creatures.

7.meaning_en: Capable of being imitated.
usage_sentences: His simple yet effective technique is highly imitable.
She has a unique style that is not easily imitable.

7.meaning_en: Take or follow as a model.
usage_sentences: Parrots are known for their ability to imitate human speech.
He tried to imitate his hero's style of painting.

7.meaning_en: A thing intended to simulate or copy something else.
usage_sentences: She wore imitation pearls that looked just like the real thing.
The painting was a clever imitation of a famous masterpiece.

7.meaning_en: Not able to be moved; motionless.
usage_sentences: He sat immobile for hours, staring out the window.
A broken engine left the car immobile on the side of the road.

7.meaning_en: A person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country.
usage_sentences: My grandparents were immigrants from Italy who came to America for a better life.
The city has a large and diverse immigrant population.

7.meaning_en: Not conforming to accepted standards of morality; wicked.
usage_sentences: Lying and cheating are considered immoral behaviors.
The book was banned for its supposedly immoral content.

7.meaning_en: Resistant to a particular infection or toxin owing to the presence of specific antibodies or sensitized white blood cells.
usage_sentences: After getting the vaccine, you will be immune to the disease.
No one is immune to criticism.
7.origin: From Latin 'immunis', meaning 'exempt from public service'.

7.meaning_en: The ability of an organism to resist a particular infection or toxin by the action of specific antibodies or sensitized white blood cells.
usage_sentences: Vaccination helps to build up immunity against serious diseases.
The diplomat claimed diplomatic immunity to avoid being arrested.

7.meaning_en: A charge of misconduct made against the holder of a public office.
usage_sentences: The president faced impeachment for his alleged crimes.
The impeachment process is a serious constitutional matter.

7.meaning_en: Make or become better.
usage_sentences: She took extra classes to improve her grades.
The weather is expected to improve tomorrow.
7.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'emprower', meaning 'to turn to profit'.

7.meaning_en: Unable to be reached.
usage_sentences: The remote mountain village is inaccessible during the winter.
The ancient ruins are located in a very inaccessible part of the jungle.

7.meaning_en: Unable to express oneself clearly or fluently.
usage_sentences: He was so nervous during the interview that he became completely inarticulate.
She made a few inarticulate sounds of protest.

7.meaning_en: Unable to be heard.
usage_sentences: His whisper was almost inaudible in the noisy room.
The sound was at a frequency that is inaudible to the human ear.

7.meaning_en: A thing that motivates or encourages one to do something.
usage_sentences: The company offered a financial incentive for employees who met their sales targets.
Tax incentives are used to encourage investment in the region.
7.origin: From late Latin 'incentivum', meaning 'something that sets the tune'.

7.meaning_en: Not able to be understood; not intelligible.
usage_sentences: The technical manual was completely incomprehensible to me.
He was speaking so fast that his words were incomprehensible.

7.meaning_en: Not able to be denied or disputed.
usage_sentences: The DNA evidence provided incontrovertible proof of his guilt.
The facts of the case are incontrovertible.
7.origin: From 'in-' (not) and 'controvertible', from Latin 'contra' (against) and 'vertere' (to turn).

7.meaning_en: (Noun) - Trouble or difficulty caused to one's personal circumstances. (Verb) - Cause trouble or difficulty to (someone).
usage_sentences: We apologize for any inconvenience caused by the delay.
I hope my late arrival did not inconvenience you.
7.origin: From late Latin 'inconvenientia', from 'in-' (not) and 'conveniens' (agreeing, suitable).

7.meaning_en: Difficult or impossible to believe.
usage_sentences: He told an incredible story about his adventure in the jungle.
