The view from the top of the mountain was absolutely incredible.

7.meaning_en: Owing money to someone.
usage_sentences: The company is heavily indebted to the banks.
I am deeply indebted to you for all your help.
7.origin: From Old French 'endeté', based on Latin 'debitum' (debt).

7.meaning_en: Beyond description; that cannot be described.
usage_sentences: The beauty of the sunset was indescribable.
He felt a sense of joy that was simply indescribable.

7.meaning_en: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
usage_sentences: The Maori are the indigenous people of New Zealand.
This type of plant is indigenous to the Amazon rainforest.
7.origin: From late Latin 'indigenus', from 'indi-' (within) and 'gignere' (to beget).

7.meaning_en: Diligent and hard-working.
usage_sentences: She is an industrious student who always completes her assignments on time.
The industrious workers finished the project ahead of schedule.

7.meaning_en: Not fit or suitable for eating.
usage_sentences: Some types of wild berries are inedible and can be poisonous.
The meal was so badly cooked that it was almost inedible.

7.meaning_en: Not eligible to do or to qualify for something.
usage_sentences: You are ineligible for the scholarship because you missed the application deadline.
Players who have tested positive for drugs are ineligible to compete.

7.meaning_en: Lacking the ability or strength to move.
usage_sentences: He lay inert in the hospital bed after the accident.
Noble gases like helium and neon are chemically inert.

7.meaning_en: Impossible to extinguish.
usage_sentences: The chemical fire was nearly inextinguishable.
She had an inextinguishable passion for learning.

7.meaning_en: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
usage_sentences: No human being is infallible; everyone makes mistakes.
He had an infallible memory and could recall every detail.
7.origin: From ecclesiastical Latin 'infallibilis', from 'in-' (not) and 'fallibilis' (liable to err).

8.meaning_en: The crime of killing a child within a year of birth.
usage_sentences: The community was shocked by the tragic case of infanticide.
Laws against infanticide are meant to protect the most vulnerable.

8.meaning_en: Limitless or endless in space, extent, or size; impossible to measure or calculate.
usage_sentences: The universe is vast and possibly infinite.
The teacher seemed to have an infinite amount of patience.

8.meaning_en: Easily set on fire.
usage_sentences: Gasoline and other inflammable liquids should be stored safely.
Warning signs indicated that the material was highly inflammable.

8.meaning_en: Not guilty of a crime or offense.
usage_sentences: The court found the defendant innocent of all charges.
He had an innocent look on his face, but I knew he was lying.

8.meaning_en: (Of a product, idea, etc.) featuring new methods; advanced and original.
usage_sentences: The company is known for its innovative approach to product design.
She came up with an innovative solution to the problem.
8.origin: From late Latin 'innovatus', from the verb 'innovare' (to renew).

8.meaning_en: Write or carve (words or symbols) on something, especially as a formal or permanent record.
usage_sentences: They decided to inscribe the date of their anniversary on their wedding rings.
His name was inscribed on the war memorial.

8.meaning_en: Words inscribed, as on a monument or in a book.
usage_sentences: The archaeologist carefully studied the ancient inscription on the stone tablet.
The inscription on the trophy read 'World Champion'.

8.meaning_en: Impossible to solve.
usage_sentences: Oil is insoluble in water.
The mystery of the missing plane seemed to be an insoluble puzzle.

8.meaning_en: Impossible to solve.
usage_sentences: The detective faced a seemingly insolvable case.
For a long time, the mathematical problem was considered insolvable.

8.meaning_en: Protected by interposing material that prevents the loss of heat or intrusion of sound.
usage_sentences: A well-insulated house stays warm in the winter and cool in the summer.
The electrical wires are insulated with a plastic coating.

8.meaning_en: Combine (one thing) with another so that they become a whole.
usage_sentences: The new software will integrate with our existing systems.
The school's goal is to integrate students of all backgrounds.

8.meaning_en: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles; moral uprightness.
usage_sentences: He is a man of great integrity who can be trusted completely.
Maintaining the structural integrity of the old bridge is a top priority.

8.meaning_en: A shy, reticent person.
usage_sentences: As an introvert, he prefers quiet evenings at home to large social gatherings.
Being an introvert doesn't mean you can't be a good leader.
8.origin: From German, from Latin 'intro-' (to the inside) and 'vertere' (to turn).

8.meaning_en: A person who intrudes, especially into a building with criminal intent.
usage_sentences: The security alarm went off when the intruder broke into the house.
She felt like an intruder at the private family meeting.

8.meaning_en: An animal lacking a backbone.
usage_sentences: Insects, spiders, and worms are all examples of invertebrates.
Over 95% of animal species are invertebrates.

8.meaning_en: A formal or systematic inquiry or examination into something.
usage_sentences: The police have launched a full investigation into the robbery.
The results of the scientific investigation will be published next month.
8.origin: From Latin 'investigare', meaning 'to track, trace out'.

8.meaning_en: A person who supervises candidates during an examination.
usage_sentences: The invigilator instructed the students to stop writing when the time was up.
An invigilator walked around the exam hall to prevent cheating.
8.origin: From the verb 'invigilate', from Latin 'invigilare' (to watch over).

8.meaning_en: (Noun) - A list of goods sent or services provided, with a statement of the sum due for these; a bill. (Verb) - Send an invoice to.
usage_sentences: Please pay the amount due on the invoice within 30 days.
Our accounts department will invoice you for the work we have completed.

8.meaning_en: Done without will or conscious control.
usage_sentences: Blinking and breathing are involuntary actions.
He let out an involuntary cry of pain when he touched the hot stove.

8.meaning_en: Impossible to harm or damage.
usage_sentences: In the myth, the hero Achilles was invulnerable except for his heel.
The fortress was believed to be invulnerable to attack.

8.meaning_en: Supply water to (land or crops) to help growth, typically by means of channels.
usage_sentences: Farmers use canals to irrigate their fields in the dry season.
The new dam will provide water to irrigate thousands of acres of land.

8.meaning_en: The supply of water to land or crops to help growth, typically by means of channels.
usage_sentences: Good irrigation is essential for agriculture in arid regions.
The government has invested in new irrigation projects.

8.meaning_en: A piece of land surrounded by water.
usage_sentences: They spent their vacation on a beautiful tropical island.
Great Britain is a large island off the coast of mainland Europe.

8.meaning_en: A small island.
usage_sentences: We took a small boat to a deserted islet for a picnic.
The bay was dotted with dozens of tiny, rocky islets.
8.origin: From Old French 'islette', a diminutive of 'isle' (island).

8.meaning_en: Far away from other places, buildings, or people; remote.
usage_sentences: He grew up in an isolated farmhouse miles from the nearest town.
After the argument, she felt very isolated from her friends.

8.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Traveling from place to place. (Noun) - A person who travels from place to place.
usage_sentences: The itinerant farm workers moved from region to region following the harvest.
He lived an itinerant lifestyle, never staying in one place for more than a few months.

8.meaning_en: A planned route or journey.
usage_sentences: The travel agent helped us plan our itinerary for our trip to Europe.
According to the itinerary, we will be visiting Rome on Tuesday.

8.meaning_en: The activity of gathering, assessing, creating, and presenting news and information.
usage_sentences: She studied journalism at university and now works for a major newspaper.
Freedom of the press is a fundamental principle of journalism.

8.meaning_en: A person who writes for newspapers, magazines, or news websites or prepares news to be broadcast.
usage_sentences: An investigative journalist uncovered a major political scandal.
The journalist was sent to report on the war from the front lines.

8.meaning_en: An act of traveling from one place to another.
usage_sentences: They embarked on a long journey across the country.
Life itself can be seen as a journey of discovery.
8.origin: From Old French 'jornee', meaning 'a day's travel'.

8.meaning_en: A feeling of great pleasure and happiness.
usage_sentences: Her face was filled with joy when she saw her family.
The birth of their first child brought them immense joy.

8.meaning_en: (Noun) - A public official appointed to decide cases in a court of law. (Verb) - Form an opinion or conclusion about.
usage_sentences: The judge sentenced the guilty man to five years in prison.
You shouldn't judge a book by its cover.

8.meaning_en: The judicial authorities of a country; judges collectively.
usage_sentences: An independent judiciary is a cornerstone of a democratic society.
The judiciary is one of the three branches of government.

8.meaning_en: The theory or philosophy of law.
usage_sentences: He is a professor of jurisprudence at the law school.
The case raised complex questions of jurisprudence.

8.meaning_en: A body of people (typically twelve in number) sworn to give a verdict in a legal case on the basis of evidence submitted to them in court.
usage_sentences: The jury found the defendant not guilty.
It took the jury several hours to reach a verdict.

8.meaning_en: (Of a sense) highly developed.
usage_sentences: Dogs have a keen sense of smell.
He has a keen interest in history and visits museums often.

8.meaning_en: One's family and relations.
usage_sentences: He invited all his kith and kin to the wedding celebration.
Your next of kin must be notified in case of an emergency.
8.origin: From Old English 'cynn', of Germanic origin.

8.meaning_en: Friends and relations.
usage_sentences: The party was a large affair, with all their kith and kin in attendance.
In times of trouble, you rely on your kith and kin for support.

8.meaning_en: (Of handwriting or print) clear enough to read.
usage_sentences: Please make sure your handwriting is legible on the exam paper.
The old sign was barely legible after years of weathering.

8.meaning_en: A piece of equipment consisting of a series of bars or steps between two upright lengths of wood, metal, or rope, used for climbing up or down something.
usage_sentences: He used a ladder to get the cat down from the tree.
She is trying to climb the corporate ladder to a management position.
8.origin: From Old English 'hlǣder', of Germanic origin.

8.meaning_en: A young sheep.
usage_sentences: The little lamb stayed close to its mother in the field.
Mary had a little lamb whose fleece was white as snow.
8.origin: From Old English 'lamb', of Germanic origin.

8.meaning_en: Denoting the second or second mentioned of two people or things.
usage_sentences: Between the book and the movie, I preferred the latter.
In the latter half of the year, the company's profits increased.

8.meaning_en: Deserving praise and commendation.
usage_sentences: Her dedication to charity work is truly laudable.
He made a laudable effort to improve his community.

8.meaning_en: Clothes and other articles that have been or are to be washed.
usage_sentences: He spent all of Sunday morning doing the laundry.
Please put your dirty clothes in the laundry basket.
8.origin: From Middle English 'lavendrie', from Latin 'lavare' (to wash).

8.meaning_en: Unwilling to work or use energy.
usage_sentences: He spent a lazy afternoon napping on the sofa.
Don't be lazy; get up and help with the chores.

8.meaning_en: (Noun) - A contract by which one party conveys land, property, services, etc., to another for a specified time, usually in return for a periodic payment. (Verb) - Grant on lease.
usage_sentences: We signed a one-year lease for the apartment.
They decided to lease a car instead of buying one.
8.origin: From Old French 'laissier', meaning 'to let, leave'.

8.meaning_en: An amount of money or property left to someone in a will.
usage_sentences: He received a small legacy from his great-aunt.
The artist's true legacy is his incredible body of work.
8.origin: From Old French 'legacie', from Latin 'legare' (to bequeath).

8.meaning_en: Permitted by law.
usage_sentences: You should always seek legal advice before signing a contract.
It is not legal to drive without a valid license.

8.meaning_en: Free time; time not spent working or occupied.
usage_sentences: What do you enjoy doing in your leisure time?
The hotel offers a wide range of leisure facilities, including a pool and a spa.
8.origin: From Old French 'leisir', from Latin 'licere' (to be permitted).

8.meaning_en: Resembling or characteristic of a lion.
usage_sentences: The old king had a majestic, leonine appearance with his great mane of white hair.
He possessed a leonine courage that was admired by all.

9.meaning_en: A person who compiles dictionaries.
usage_sentences: Samuel Johnson was a famous 18th-century lexicographer.
A lexicographer must be meticulous and have a deep love for language.

9.meaning_en: The art or science of compiling dictionaries.
usage_sentences: The study of lexicography reveals how languages change over time.
He is an expert in the field of lexicography.

9.meaning_en: The vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge.
usage_sentences: The lexicon of computer science includes terms like 'algorithm' and 'bandwidth'.
She has an impressive lexicon for someone her age.

9.meaning_en: (Noun) - An advocate of principles of liberty and free will. (Adjective) - Relating to or denoting a political philosophy that upholds liberty as a core principle.
usage_sentences: As a libertarian, he believes in minimal government intervention.
The libertarian party advocates for free markets and individual rights.

9.meaning_en: A short band of tough, flexible, fibrous connective tissue which connects two bones or cartilages or holds together a joint.
usage_sentences: The athlete tore a ligament in his knee during the game.
Strong ligaments are crucial for joint stability.

9.meaning_en: The focus of public attention.
usage_sentences: The young actor was suddenly thrust into the limelight after his first hit movie.
Some celebrities enjoy being in the limelight, while others prefer a private life.
9.origin: From 'limelight', a type of stage lighting used in the 19th century.

9.meaning_en: Able to read and write.
usage_sentences: The government's goal is to ensure that every citizen is literate.
You need to be computer literate to find a good job these days.

9.meaning_en: Farm animals regarded as an asset.
usage_sentences: The farmer raises cattle, sheep, and other livestock.
A drought can have a devastating impact on livestock.
9.origin: A compound of 'live' and 'stock' (in the sense of farm property).

9.meaning_en: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
usage_sentences: He gave a lucid explanation of the complex scientific theory.
She had a lucid dream where she was aware that she was dreaming.

9.meaning_en: Producing a great deal of profit.
usage_sentences: He left his job to start a lucrative online business.
The tech industry can be a very lucrative field for skilled professionals.

9.meaning_en: The SI unit of luminous flux, equal to the amount of light emitted per second in a unit solid angle of one steradian by a uniform point source of one candela.
usage_sentences: This light bulb has an output of 800 lumens.
When buying a projector, check the lumen rating for brightness.

9.meaning_en: A person who inspires or influences others, especially one prominent in a particular sphere.
usage_sentences: The conference was attended by many luminaries from the world of science.
She is considered a luminary in the field of modern art.

9.meaning_en: A single payment made at a particular time, as opposed to a series of smaller payments or installments.
usage_sentences: He chose to receive his lottery winnings as a lump sum.
The retirement plan offers the option of a lump sum payout.

9.meaning_en: Of or relating to the moon.
usage_sentences: The Apollo missions were part of the lunar exploration program.
A lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth passes between the Sun and the Moon.

9.meaning_en: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or someone less powerful than oneself.
usage_sentences: The winning team was magnanimous in victory and praised their opponents.
It was magnanimous of him to forgive the person who had wronged him.

9.meaning_en: Extremely beautiful, elaborate, or impressive.
usage_sentences: The palace was filled with magnificent paintings and sculptures.
The view from the mountaintop was absolutely magnificent.

9.meaning_en: Cause or enable (a condition or state of affairs) to continue.
usage_sentences: It is important to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly.
Regular maintenance is required to keep the car in good condition.
9.origin: From Old French 'maintenir', from Latin 'manu tenere' (to hold in the hand).

9.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who is dissatisfied and rebellious. (Adjective) - Dissatisfied with the existing state of affairs.
usage_sentences: A small group of malcontents started a protest against the new policy.
He was a malcontent employee who was always complaining about the company.

9.meaning_en: (Verb) - Fail to function normally or satisfactorily. (Noun) - Failure to function normally.
usage_sentences: A software malfunction caused the entire computer system to crash.
The machine began to malfunction due to a faulty part.

9.meaning_en: (Of a metal or other material) able to be hammered or pressed permanently out of shape without breaking or cracking.
usage_sentences: Gold is a malleable metal that can be hammered into very thin sheets.
The minds of young children are malleable and easily influenced.

9.meaning_en: Lack of proper nutrition, caused by not having enough to eat, not eating enough of the right things, or being unable to make use of the food that one does eat.
usage_sentences: Many children in developing countries suffer from malnutrition.
A poor diet can lead to malnutrition even in wealthy nations.

9.meaning_en: A warm-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that is distinguished by the possession of hair or fur, females secrete milk for the nourishment of the young, and (typically) the birth of live young.
usage_sentences: Humans, dogs, elephants, and whales are all examples of mammals.
One of the defining characteristics of mammals is that they produce milk for their young.

9.meaning_en: A public declaration of policy and aims, especially one issued before an election by a political party or candidate.
usage_sentences: The political party released its manifesto outlining its plans for the country.
The artist's manifesto explained her vision for a new art movement.

9.meaning_en: A book, document, or piece of music written by hand rather than typed or printed.
usage_sentences: The author submitted the manuscript of her new novel to the publisher.
The museum has a collection of rare medieval manuscripts.
9.origin: From medieval Latin 'manuscriptus', from 'manu' (by hand) and 'scriptus' (written).

9.meaning_en: Of, found in, or relating to the sea.
usage_sentences: A marine biologist studies the plants and animals that live in the ocean.
Dolphins and whales are marine mammals.

9.meaning_en: Relating to war or armed forces.
usage_sentences: Karate and judo are types of martial arts.
The government declared martial law to restore order after the riots.
9.origin: From Latin 'martialis', from 'Mars', the Roman god of war.

9.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who is killed because of their religious or other beliefs. (Verb) - Kill (someone) for their beliefs.
usage_sentences: Joan of Arc is considered a martyr by many.
He became a martyr for the cause of freedom.

9.meaning_en: Excessively concerned with material possessions; preoccupied with material rather than spiritual or intellectual things.
usage_sentences: He lives a very materialistic lifestyle, always buying the latest gadgets.
Modern society is often criticized for being too materialistic.

9.meaning_en: A woman who is the head of a family or tribe.
usage_sentences: The old matriarch ruled over her large family with wisdom and authority.
In elephant herds, the leader is always the oldest female, the matriarch.

9.meaning_en: The killing of one's mother.
usage_sentences: The defendant was on trial for the crime of matricide.
The story of Orestes in Greek mythology involves matricide.

9.meaning_en: Relating to the Middle Ages.
usage_sentences: We visited a medieval castle that was built over 800 years ago.
The museum has an extensive collection of medieval art.

9.meaning_en: Producing or having a pleasant tune; tuneful.
usage_sentences: The melodious sound of the flute filled the air.
She has a beautiful, melodious singing voice.

9.meaning_en: An object kept as a reminder or souvenir of a person or event.
usage_sentences: I kept the seashell as a memento of our trip to the beach.
The photograph was a precious memento of her grandparents.

9.meaning_en: A historical account or biography written from personal knowledge or special sources.
usage_sentences: The retired general published a memoir about his time in the army.
Her memoir gives a fascinating insight into the world of politics.

9.meaning_en: The branch of science and technology concerned with the properties of metals and their production and purification.
usage_sentences: He studied metallurgy to learn how to extract iron from its ore.
Advances in metallurgy were crucial for the Industrial Revolution.

9.meaning_en: An extreme fear of germs.
usage_sentences: Due to his microphobia, he washed his hands constantly.
A person with microphobia may avoid public places.

9.meaning_en: An optical instrument used for viewing very small objects, such as mineral samples or animal or plant cells, typically magnified several hundred times.
usage_sentences: The biologist used a powerful microscope to observe the cells.
We learned how to use a microscope in our science class.

9.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who migrates to another country, especially in order to find employment or better living conditions. (Adjective) - Migratory.
usage_sentences: Migrant workers often travel long distances to find seasonal jobs.
Many migrant birds fly south for the winter.

9.meaning_en: Seasonal movement of animals from one region to another.
usage_sentences: The annual migration of wildebeest across the Serengeti is a spectacular event.
Economic hardship is a major driver of human migration.

9.meaning_en: (Verb) - Imitate (someone or their actions or words), especially in order to entertain or ridicule. (Adjective) - Imitative. (Noun) - A person skilled in imitating others.
usage_sentences: The comedian was famous for his ability to mimic politicians.
The insect has markings that mimic the eyes of a predator.

9.meaning_en: Conscious or aware of something.
usage_sentences: Please be mindful of the other guests and keep the noise down.
He is very mindful of his health and eats a balanced diet.

9.meaning_en: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
9.meaning_hi: मानव द्वेषी/मनुष्य जाति से घृणा करनेवाला
usage_sentences: The old misanthrope lived alone and chased away any visitors.
After being betrayed, he became a bitter misanthrope.

9.meaning_en: A dislike of humankind.
usage_sentences: The main character in the play is consumed by misanthropy.
His cynical novels are full of misanthropy and despair.

9.meaning_en: A person who hoards wealth and spends as little money as possible.
usage_sentences: Despite being a millionaire, the old miser lived in poverty.
He's such a miser that he won't even turn on the heating in winter.

9.meaning_en: A person who hates marriage.
usage_sentences: As a confirmed misogamist, he vowed to remain a bachelor for life.
Her two failed marriages turned her into a misogamist.

9.meaning_en: A person who dislikes, despises, or is strongly prejudiced against women.
9.meaning_hi: स्त्री द्वेषी/नारी जाति से घृणा करनेवाला
usage_sentences: His misogynist comments caused a public outcry.
The boss was fired for being a misogynist and treating female employees unfairly.

9.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Assisting or intended to assist memory. (Noun) - A device such as a pattern of letters, ideas, or associations that assists in remembering something.
usage_sentences: I use a mnemonic to remember the order of the planets.
'Roy G. Biv' is a popular mnemonic for the colors of the rainbow.

9.meaning_en: (Noun) - A large crowd of people, especially one that is disorderly and intent on causing trouble or violence. (Verb) - Crowd around (someone) in a disorderly and intimidating way.
usage_sentences: An angry mob gathered outside the courthouse to protest the verdict.
The celebrity was mobbed by fans as soon as he left the hotel.
9.origin: Short for 'mobile vulgus', a Latin phrase meaning 'fickle crowd'.

9.meaning_en: Lasting for a very short time; brief.
usage_sentences: There was a momentary pause in the conversation.
For a momentary lapse in concentration, he lost the game.

9.meaning_en: A sovereign ruler, especially a king, queen, or emperor.
usage_sentences: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning monarch in British history.
The monarch butterfly is known for its long migration.

10.meaning_en: Sovereignty by one person.
usage_sentences: The United Kingdom is a constitutional monarchy.
The French Revolution led to the end of the monarchy in France.

10.meaning_en: A building or buildings occupied by monks living under religious vows.
usage_sentences: The old monastery was perched high on a remote mountaintop.
He decided to leave the city and join a monastery.

10.meaning_en: A member of a religious community of men typically living under vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience.
usage_sentences: The monks spent their days in prayer and meditation.
A Buddhist monk in a saffron robe walked silently down the street.

10.meaning_en: The practice or state of being married to only one person at a time.
usage_sentences: Monogamy is the most common form of marriage in Western cultures.
Many species of birds practice monogamy and mate for life.

10.meaning_en: A statue, building, or other structure erected to commemorate a famous or notable person or event.
usage_sentences: The Taj Mahal is a magnificent monument to love.
A new monument was built to honor the war veterans.

10.meaning_en: The state of being subject to death.
usage_sentences: The high infant mortality rate is a serious concern.
He was suddenly confronted with his own mortality after the accident.

10.meaning_en: The ability to deal with more than one task at the time.
usage_sentences: Working mothers are often experts at multitasking.
Multitasking can sometimes lead to more mistakes and lower quality work.

10.meaning_en: Very numerous.
usage_sentences: The city has multitudinous challenges, from traffic to pollution.
He faced multitudinous tasks upon starting his new job.

10.meaning_en: A body of a human being or animal that has been embalmed and dried and so preserved for a very long time.
usage_sentences: The museum exhibition featured an ancient Egyptian mummy.
Scientists studied the mummy to learn about life in the past.
10.origin: From medieval Latin 'mummia', from Arabic 'mūmiyā' (embalmed body).

10.meaning_en: A building in which objects of historical, scientific, artistic, or cultural interest are stored and exhibited.
usage_sentences: We spent the afternoon at the natural history museum.
The Louvre in Paris is one of the most famous museums in the world.
10.origin: From Latin 'museum', from Greek 'mouseion' (seat of the Muses).

10.meaning_en: Something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain.
usage_sentences: The disappearance of the ship remains a mystery to this day.
She loves reading mystery novels and trying to solve the crime.

10.meaning_en: (Of a person or action) showing a lack of experience, wisdom, or judgement.
usage_sentences: She was too naive to realize that he was trying to cheat her.
It was naive of him to trust a complete stranger with his money.
10.origin: From French 'naïf, naïve', from Latin 'nativus' (native, natural).

10.meaning_en: Excessive interest in or admiration of oneself and one's physical appearance.
usage_sentences: His constant need for attention was a clear sign of his narcissism.
Social media can sometimes encourage narcissism.
10.origin: From Narcissus, a figure in Greek mythology who fell in love with his own reflection.

10.meaning_en: A person who has an excessive interest in or admiration of themselves.
usage_sentences: It is very difficult to have a healthy relationship with a narcissist.
The narcissist constantly steered the conversation back to himself.
10.origin: From Narcissus, a figure in Greek mythology.

10.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Belonging originally to a particular place; indigenous. (Noun) - A person born in a particular place or country.
usage_sentences: The kangaroo is native to Australia.
Although he has lived abroad for years, he is a native of India.

10.meaning_en: So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering; insignificant.
usage_sentences: The difference in price between the two products was negligible.
The risk of side effects from the medication is negligible.

10.meaning_en: A district, especially one of a town or city, regarded as a community.
usage_sentences: They live in a quiet, friendly neighbourhood.
The new park will be a great asset for the entire neighbourhood.

10.meaning_en: A physician who specializes in nephrology.
usage_sentences: The patient with kidney failure was under the care of a nephrologist.
A nephrologist treats diseases related to the kidneys.

10.meaning_en: The practice among those with power or influence of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs.
usage_sentences: He was accused of nepotism after hiring his unqualified son for a top position.
Nepotism is a form of corruption that undermines fairness.

10.meaning_en: A physician skilled in the diagnosis and treatment of disease of the nervous system.
usage_sentences: She was referred to a neurologist after experiencing persistent headaches.
A neurologist treats conditions like epilepsy, stroke, and Parkinson's disease.

10.meaning_en: The branch of medicine or biology that deals with the anatomy, functions, and organic disorders of nerves and the nervous system.
usage_sentences: He is a leading expert in the field of neurology.
The hospital has a renowned neurology department.

10.meaning_en: The scientific study of the nervous system.
usage_sentences: Neuroscience is a rapidly advancing field with many new discoveries.
She is pursuing a PhD in cognitive neuroscience.

10.meaning_en: The devising or choosing of names for things, especially in a science or other discipline.
usage_sentences: The botanical nomenclature is governed by a strict set of rules.
Understanding the correct chemical nomenclature is essential for a chemist.

10.meaning_en: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past, typically for a period or place with happy personal associations.
usage_sentences: Looking at old family photos filled him with a sense of nostalgia.
The song was pure nostalgia, taking him back to his college days.

10.meaning_en: Famous or well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
usage_sentences: Al Capone was a notorious gangster in the 1920s.
The politician is notorious for his dishonesty.

10.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Having no legal or binding force; invalid. (Noun) - Nothing; zero.
usage_sentences: Without the owner's signature, the contract is null and void.
The result of the calculation was null.

10.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Not discovered or known about; uncertain. (Verb) - Keep from being seen; conceal.
usage_sentences: He was an obscure poet whose work was only discovered after his death.
The heavy fog threatened to obscure our view of the road.

10.meaning_en: A room or building housing an astronomical telescope or other scientific equipment for the study of natural phenomena.
usage_sentences: Astronomers at the observatory discovered a new comet.
The mountain-top location provides the observatory with clear views of the sky.

10.meaning_en: A person's job or profession.
usage_sentences: Please state your name, age, and occupation.
Teaching is a very rewarding occupation.
10.origin: From Latin 'occupatio(n-)', from the verb 'occupare' (to seize).

10.meaning_en: A plane figure with eight straight sides and eight angles.
usage_sentences: A standard stop sign has the shape of an octagon.
The building was designed with an octagon at its center.

10.meaning_en: A person who is from 80 to 89 years old.
usage_sentences: Despite being an octogenarian, he still enjoys a game of tennis.
The sprightly octogenarian walked five miles every day.

10.meaning_en: A cephalopod mollusk with eight sucker-bearing arms, a soft body, and no internal skeleton.
usage_sentences: The octopus is a highly intelligent marine animal.
An octopus can change its color to blend in with its surroundings.

10.meaning_en: Not located in the center; away from the center.
usage_sentences: The picture on the wall was slightly off-centre.
He has a quirky, off-centre sense of humor.

10.meaning_en: Having unlimited power; able to do anything.
usage_sentences: In many religions, God is described as an omnipotent being.
The dictator ruled the country as if he were omnipotent.

10.meaning_en: Knowing everything.
usage_sentences: The novel is told from the perspective of an omniscient narrator.
It is impossible for any human to be truly omniscient.
10.origin: From late Latin 'omniscient-', from 'omnis' (all) and 'scire' (to know).

10.meaning_en: Present everywhere simultaneously.
usage_sentences: In today's world, the influence of technology seems to be omnipresent.
God is believed by some to be omnipresent.

10.meaning_en: An animal or person that eats food of both plant and animal origin.
usage_sentences: Bears and humans are examples of omnivores.
An omnivore's diet is varied, including fruits, vegetables, and meat.

10.meaning_en: Not able to be seen through; not transparent.
usage_sentences: The frosted glass in the bathroom door is opaque for privacy.
His legal jargon was dense and opaque, making it hard to understand.

10.meaning_en: A person who tends to be hopeful and confident about the future or the success of something.
usage_sentences: Despite the challenges, she remains an eternal optimist.
An optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty.

10.meaning_en: A public speaker, especially one who is eloquent or skilled.
usage_sentences: Martin Luther King Jr. was a powerful and inspiring orator.
The skilled orator held the audience's attention for the entire speech.

10.meaning_en: An intentional planting of trees or shrubs that is maintained for food production.
usage_sentences: They spent the afternoon picking apples in the orchard.
The farm has a large cherry orchard that is popular in the spring.

10.meaning_en: A large instrumental ensemble typical of classical music, that combines instruments from different families.
usage_sentences: The symphony orchestra performed Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.
She plays the violin in the city's youth orchestra.
10.origin: From Greek 'orkhēstra', the space where the chorus danced in a theater.

10.meaning_en: (Noun) - An authoritative command, direction, or instruction. (Verb) - Give an authoritative direction or instruction to do something.
usage_sentences: The general gave the order to attack.
Please put the books in alphabetical order.

10.meaning_en: (Noun) - A child whose parents are dead. (Verb) - Cause a child to become an orphan.
usage_sentences: The charity provides housing and education for orphans.
He was left an orphan at a very young age.

10.meaning_en: Conforming to what is traditionally accepted as right or true; established and approved.
usage_sentences: He holds very orthodox views on religion and society.
The doctor first tried several orthodox treatments before suggesting surgery.

10.meaning_en: Fail to notice (something).
usage_sentences: In his haste, he managed to overlook a crucial detail.
Our hotel room balcony will overlook the sea.

10.meaning_en: Bury or drown beneath a huge mass of something, especially water or emotion.
usage_sentences: She was overwhelmed with gratitude for all the help she received.
Don't let the amount of work overwhelm you; just take it one task at a time.
10.origin: From Middle English, from 'over' and 'whelmen' (to turn upside down).

10.meaning_en: The belief that war and violence are unjustifiable and that disputes should be settled by peaceful means.
usage_sentences: He was a strong advocate of pacifism and non-violent protest.
Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy was deeply rooted in pacifism.

10.meaning_en: A person who believes in pacifism or is opposed to war or to violence of any kind.
usage_sentences: As a pacifist, he refused to join the army.
The protest was led by a group of dedicated pacifists.

10.meaning_en: Quell the anger, agitation, or excitement of.
usage_sentences: The mother tried to pacify her crying baby with a toy.
The diplomat's speech was intended to pacify the angry crowd.
10.origin: From Old French 'pacifier', from Latin 'pax' (peace) and '-ficare' (to make).

11.meaning_en: A formal agreement between individuals or parties.
usage_sentences: The two rival companies signed a pact to work together on the project.
They made a pact as children to always remain friends.

11.meaning_en: A solution or remedy for all ills or difficulties.
usage_sentences: He believes that education is the panacea for all of society's problems.
Unfortunately, there is no panacea that will make you rich overnight.

11.meaning_en: (Noun) - (of a disease) prevalent over a whole country or the world. (Adjective) - An outbreak of a pandemic disease.
usage_sentences: The 1918 flu pandemic was one of the deadliest in history.
Health organizations are constantly monitoring for potential pandemic threats.

11.meaning_en: (Noun) - Sudden uncontrollable fear or anxiety, often causing wildly unthinking behavior. (Verb) - Feel or cause to feel panic.
usage_sentences: When the fire alarm rang, there was a moment of panic in the theater.
Don't panic, just stay calm and walk to the nearest exit.
11.origin: From Greek 'panikos', relating to the god Pan, who was said to cause groundless fear.

11.meaning_en: An unbroken view of the whole region surrounding an observer.
usage_sentences: From the top of the tower, you can see a stunning panorama of the city.
The book provides a panorama of European history.

11.meaning_en: (Verb) - Breathe with short, quick breaths, typically from exertion or excitement. (Noun) - A short, quick breath.
usage_sentences: After running up the stairs, he was panting heavily.
The dog sat in the shade, its tongue out, panting in the heat.
11.origin: From Old French 'pantaisier', possibly from Greek 'phantasioun' (to have visions).

11.meaning_en: Independent photographers who take pictures of high-profile people, typically without their consent.
usage_sentences: The celebrity was surrounded by a swarm of paparazzi as she left the restaurant.
She sued the paparazzi for invading her privacy.
11.origin: From 'Paparazzo', the name of a news photographer in the Italian film La Dolce Vita.

11.meaning_en: An organism that lives in or on another organism (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the host's expense.
usage_sentences: A tick is a parasite that feeds on the blood of animals.
He called his lazy brother a parasite because he lived off their parents' money.
11.origin: From Greek 'parasitos', meaning '(person) eating at another's table'.

11.meaning_en: (Noun) - The release of a prisoner temporarily or permanently before the completion of a sentence, on the promise of good behavior. (Verb) - Release (a prisoner) on parole.
usage_sentences: He was released from prison on parole after serving ten years.
The board denied his request for parole.
11.origin: From French 'parole', meaning 'word, speech' (in the sense of 'word of honor').

11.meaning_en: (Noun) - A government authority or licence conferring a right or title for a set period, especially the sole right to exclude others from making, using, or selling an invention.
usage_sentences: The inventor filed a patent for her new device.
The company holds several patents on its technology.
11.origin: From Old French 'lettre patente' (open letter), from Latin 'patere' (to be open).

11.meaning_en: The science of the causes and effects of diseases.
usage_sentences: The pathology report confirmed that the tumor was benign.
He is a professor of pathology at the medical school.

11.meaning_en: The male head of a family or tribe.
usage_sentences: As the patriarch of the family, his decision was final.
The old patriarch was respected by everyone in the community.

11.meaning_en: The killing of one's father.
usage_sentences: In the ancient Greek myth, Oedipus unknowingly commits patricide.
He was convicted of the horrific crime of patricide.

11.meaning_en: Relating to or based on relationship to the father or descent through the male line.
usage_sentences: Many traditional societies have a patrilineal system of inheritance.
In a patrilineal culture, family names are passed down from father to son.

11.meaning_en: Property inherited from one's father or male ancestor.
usage_sentences: He spent his entire patrimony on risky investments.
The ancient castle was part of his family's patrimony.

11.meaning_en: A person who vigorously supports their country and is prepared to defend it against enemies or detractors.
usage_sentences: The soldiers were hailed as heroes and patriots.
A true patriot is one who is loyal to their country at all times.

11.meaning_en: (Verb) - Keep watch over (an area) by regularly walking or travelling around in it in order to maintain order or security. (Noun) - A person or group of people sent out to keep watch over an area.
usage_sentences: The security guard has to patrol the building every hour.
A police patrol car was seen in the neighborhood.

11.meaning_en: The method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject or theoretical concept.
usage_sentences: The new teacher was trained in the latest methods of pedagogy.
His pedagogy focuses on interactive and student-centered learning.

11.meaning_en: A punishment imposed or incurred for a breach of law, rule, or contract.
usage_sentences: The penalty for speeding is a heavy fine.
In football, a foul inside the box results in a penalty kick.

11.meaning_en: A piece of land almost surrounded by water or projecting out into a body of water.
usage_sentences: The state of Florida is a large peninsula.
The Korean Peninsula is located in East Asia.

11.meaning_en: Persistence in doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.
usage_sentences: With hard work and perseverance, he eventually achieved his goal.
Perseverance is the key to success in any field.

11.meaning_en: People employed in an organization or engaged in an organized undertaking such as military service.
usage_sentences: All personnel are required to attend the safety training.
The company is hiring new personnel for its marketing department.

11.meaning_en: A person who tends to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.
usage_sentences: A pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity.
Don't be such a pessimist; try to look on the bright side.

11.meaning_en: A substance used for destroying insects or other organisms harmful to cultivated plants or to animals.
usage_sentences: Farmers spray pesticides on their crops to protect them from insects.
Organic farming avoids the use of synthetic pesticides.

11.meaning_en: A person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
usage_sentences: The wealthy philanthropist donated millions to build a new hospital.
She is a well-known philanthropist and supporter of the arts.

11.meaning_en: The desire to promote the welfare of others, expressed especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
usage_sentences: The foundation is dedicated to philanthropy and supports various charities.
His act of philanthropy has helped thousands of people.

11.meaning_en: A person who likes, admires, and supports women.
usage_sentences: As a true philogynist, he actively campaigned for women's rights.
His writings show him to be a philogynist, celebrating the strength of female characters.

11.meaning_en: A person engaged or learned in philosophy, especially as an academic discipline.
usage_sentences: Socrates and Plato were ancient Greek philosophers.
The philosopher pondered the meaning of life.

11.meaning_en: An extreme or irrational fear of or aversion to something.
usage_sentences: He has a phobia of spiders and cannot even look at a picture of one.
Claustrophobia is a common phobia involving the fear of enclosed spaces.

11.meaning_en: The branch of linguistics that deals with the sounds of speech and their production, and acoustic properties.
usage_sentences: Studying phonetics can help you improve your pronunciation in a foreign language.
Phonetics is the science of speech sounds.

11.meaning_en: A person qualified to practice medicine; a doctor.
usage_sentences: You should consult a physician if your symptoms persist.
She is a highly respected physician specializing in internal medicine.
11.origin: From Old French 'fisicien', from 'fisique' (art of healing).

11.meaning_en: The branch of biology that deals with the normal functions of living organisms and their parts.
usage_sentences: He is studying human physiology to understand how the body works.
Plant physiology is concerned with the life processes of plants.

11.meaning_en: Treatment to restore, maintain, and make the most of a patient’s mobility, function, and well-being.
usage_sentences: After the surgery, he needed physiotherapy to regain strength in his leg.
Physiotherapy can help with a wide range of injuries and conditions.

11.meaning_en: The twelfth sign of the zodiac, which the sun enters about February 19.
usage_sentences: Her birthday is in early March, so her zodiac sign is Pisces.
Pisces is represented by two fish swimming in opposite directions.

11.meaning_en: Fish-eating.
usage_sentences: Dolphins, penguins, and kingfishers are all piscivorous animals.
The fossilized remains suggest it was a large, piscivorous dinosaur.

11.meaning_en: (Noun) - A solemn promise or undertaking. (Verb) - Commit (oneself or one's organization) to a course of action.
usage_sentences: The students made a pledge to keep their school clean.
The company pledged to donate one million dollars to the charity.
11.origin: From Old French 'plege', of Germanic origin.

11.meaning_en: An abundance.
usage_sentences: The harvest festival celebrates the plentitude of the earth.
The library offers a plentitude of books on every conceivable subject.

11.meaning_en: A person who fits and repairs the pipes and fittings of water supply, sanitation, or heating systems.
usage_sentences: We had to call a plumber to fix the leaky faucet.
The plumber installed a new water heater in our house.
11.origin: From Old French 'plommier', from Latin 'plumbum' (lead), as pipes were once made of lead.

11.meaning_en: A small platform on which a person may stand to be heard or to conduct an orchestra.
usage_sentences: The speaker stood at the podium to address the audience.
The top three athletes stood on the winner's podium to receive their medals.

11.meaning_en: The activities associated with the governance of a country or area.
usage_sentences: He decided to enter politics to serve the public.
Office politics can make the workplace very unpleasant.

11.meaning_en: A person who practices polygamy.
usage_sentences: In some cultures, it was common for a king to be a polygamist.
The leader of the sect was a polygamist with several wives.

11.meaning_en: A plane figure with at least three straight sides and angles, and typically five or more.
usage_sentences: Triangles, squares, and pentagons are all types of polygon.
The teacher taught the students how to calculate the area of a polygon.

11.meaning_en: A person who believes in or worships more than one god.
usage_sentences: The ancient Greeks and Romans were polytheists.
A polytheist worships a pantheon of different gods and goddesses.

11.meaning_en: Having a large population.
usage_sentences: China is the world's most populous country.
The city grew into a populous metropolitan area.

11.meaning_en: A town or city with a harbor where ships load or unload.
usage_sentences: The large cargo ship sailed into the port.
Mumbai is a major port city in India.

11.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Occurring or done after death. (Noun) - An examination of a dead body to determine the cause of death.
usage_sentences: A postmortem examination revealed the cause of death.
The team conducted a postmortem on the failed project to see what went wrong.

11.meaning_en: Cause or arrange for (something) to take place at a later time than that first scheduled.
usage_sentences: They had to postpone the wedding due to unforeseen circumstances.
The meeting has been postponed until next Friday.

11.meaning_en: Safe to drink; drinkable.
usage_sentences: The water from the tap is not potable; you should boil it first.
The hikers carried a filter to make river water potable.

11.meaning_en: (Noun) - The actual application or employment of an idea, belief, or method. (Verb) - Repeatedly perform (an activity) or regularly exercise (a skill) in order to improve one's proficiency or facility.
usage_sentences: It takes a lot of practice to become a skilled musician.
She wants to open her own medical practice after she graduates.
11.origin: From Old French 'practiser', based on Greek 'praktikos' (concerned with action).

11.meaning_en: Say or estimate that (a specified thing) will happen in the future or will be a consequence of something.
usage_sentences: Weather forecasters predict that it will rain tomorrow.
It is difficult to predict the outcome of the election.

12.meaning_en: Preconceived opinion that is not based on reason or actual experience.
usage_sentences: We must work to eliminate racial prejudice from our society.
His prejudice against modern art was obvious.

12.meaning_en: Make (something) ready for use or consideration.
usage_sentences: The chef began to prepare the ingredients for the meal.
You need to prepare well for the upcoming exam.
12.origin: From Latin 'praeparare', from 'prae-' (in advance) and 'parare' (to make ready).

12.meaning_en: Advise and authorize the use of (a medicine or treatment) for someone.
usage_sentences: The doctor will prescribe antibiotics for your infection.
The law prescribes a specific penalty for that crime.
12.origin: From Latin 'praescribere', from 'prae-' (in advance) and 'scribere' (to write).

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - A special right, advantage, or immunity granted or available only to a particular person or group of people.
usage_sentences: Access to good education should be a right, not a privilege.
It was a privilege to meet such a distinguished scientist.
12.origin: From Latin 'privilegium', meaning 'law concerning an individual'.

12.meaning_en: Delay or postpone action; put off doing something.
usage_sentences: If you procrastinate, you will have to do all your work at the last minute.
He tends to procrastinate on difficult tasks.

12.meaning_en: The action of delaying or postponing something.
usage_sentences: Procrastination is the thief of time.
She overcame her habit of procrastination and became much more productive.
12.origin: From Latin 'procrastinare' (to put off until tomorrow).

12.meaning_en: A high degree of competence or skill; expertise.
usage_sentences: She demonstrated a high level of proficiency in several languages.
The job requires proficiency in computer programming.
12.origin: From 'proficient', from Latin 'proficere' (to advance, make progress).

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - An outline of something, especially a person's face, as seen from one side. (Verb) - Describe (someone or something) in a profile.
usage_sentences: The artist drew a beautiful profile of the woman.
Please create an online profile to apply for the job.
12.origin: From Italian 'profilo', from 'profilare' (to draw in outline).

12.meaning_en: Information, especially of a biased or misleading nature, used to promote a political cause or point of view.
usage_sentences: The government used propaganda to win support for the war.
It is important to be able to distinguish between news and propaganda.
12.origin: From modern Latin 'de propaganda fide' (for propagating the faith), a committee of cardinals.

12.meaning_en: A person regarded as being inspired to speak for God or a god.
usage_sentences: Moses is considered a prophet in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
The ancient prophet warned the people of impending disaster.

12.meaning_en: The action of driving or pushing forward.
usage_sentences: The boat is powered by a jet propulsion system.
He studied different methods of rocket propulsion.
12.origin: From late Latin 'propulsio(n-)', from 'propellere' (to drive forward).

12.meaning_en: Concern for one's own area or region at the expense of national unity or wider interests.
usage_sentences: His provincialism prevented him from appreciating the culture of other regions.
The politician was accused of provincialism for focusing only on his home state.

12.meaning_en: An expert or specialist in psychology.
usage_sentences: She decided to see a psychologist to help her deal with stress.
A child psychologist can help children with behavioral problems.

12.meaning_en: Having a sharply strong taste or smell.
usage_sentences: The pungent smell of onions and garlic filled the kitchen.
He made a pungent criticism of the government's policies.

12.meaning_en: (Verb) - (of a cat) make a low continuous vibratory sound expressing contentment. (Noun) - A low continuous vibratory sound expressive of contentment, made by a cat.
usage_sentences: The cat began to purr as she stroked its fur.
The engine of the luxury car had a low, satisfying purr.

12.meaning_en: Follow (someone or something) in order to catch or overtake them.
usage_sentences: The police car had to pursue the speeding vehicle.
She decided to pursue a career in medicine.
12.origin: From Old French 'poursuir', from Latin 'prosequi' (to prosecute).

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who dishonestly claims to have special knowledge and skill in some field, typically medicine.
usage_sentences: The so-called doctor was just a quack selling useless remedies.
He was exposed as a quack by a medical investigation.
12.origin: Short for 'quacksalver', from Dutch, probably meaning 'hawker of salve'.

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - An animal which has four feet, especially an ungulate mammal.
usage_sentences: Horses, dogs, and elephants are all quadrupeds.
Most land mammals are quadrupeds.

12.meaning_en: Reject as invalid, especially by legal procedure.
usage_sentences: The higher court decided to quash the original conviction.
He tried to quash the rumors that were spreading about him.
12.origin: From Old French 'quasser', from Latin 'cassus' (null, void).

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - A long or arduous search for something. (Verb) - Search for something.
usage_sentences: The knights went on a quest to find the Holy Grail.
Her quest for knowledge led her to travel the world.
12.origin: From Old French 'queste', from Latin 'quaerere' (to seek).

12.meaning_en: To the utmost or absolute extent or degree; absolutely; completely.
usage_sentences: The movie was quite good, although not the best I've seen.
Are you quite sure you locked the door?
12.origin: From Old French 'quite', from Latin 'quietus' (at rest).

12.meaning_en: The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the meeting valid.
usage_sentences: The meeting could not begin because they did not have a quorum.
Once a quorum was present, the committee proceeded to vote.
12.origin: From Latin 'quorum', meaning 'of whom', from the wording of commissions for justices of the peace.

12.meaning_en: The emission of energy as electromagnetic waves or as moving particles.
usage_sentences: Exposure to high levels of radiation can be very dangerous.
Radiation therapy is used to treat some types of cancer.

12.meaning_en: A medical specialist who uses radioactive substances and X-rays in the diagnosis and treatment of disease.
usage_sentences: The radiologist examined the X-ray to look for a broken bone.
A radiologist interprets medical images like CT scans and MRIs.

12.meaning_en: The science dealing with X-rays and other high-energy radiation, especially the use of such radiation for the diagnosis and treatment of disease.
usage_sentences: She is training to be a technician in the hospital's radiology department.
Radiology plays a vital role in modern medicine.

12.meaning_en: Smelling or tasting unpleasant as a result of being old and stale.
usage_sentences: The butter had gone rancid after being left out of the fridge.
There was a rancid smell coming from the garbage bin.

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - A sum of money or other payment demanded or paid for the release of a prisoner. (Verb) - Redeem (a prisoner) for ransom.
usage_sentences: The kidnappers demanded a huge ransom for the safe return of the child.
The family paid the ransom and the hostage was released.
12.origin: From Old French 'rançon', from Latin 'redemptio' (buying back).

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who rises in opposition or armed resistance against an established government or ruler. (Verb) - Rise in opposition or armed resistance to an established government or ruler.
usage_sentences: A group of rebels attacked the army outpost.
As a teenager, he would often rebel against his parents' rules.

12.meaning_en: A person or thing that receives or is awarded something.
usage_sentences: She was the proud recipient of the employee of the year award.
Please write the name of the recipient on the package.

12.meaning_en: Avoiding the company of other people; solitary.
usage_sentences: The famous author became reclusive in his later years.
He lived a reclusive life in a small cabin in the mountains.

12.meaning_en: Put right; correct.
usage_sentences: We need to rectify the error in the financial report.
He apologized and promised to rectify the situation.
12.origin: From late Latin 'rectificare', from 'rectus' (right) and '-ficare' (to make).

12.meaning_en: Contained by or consisting of straight lines.
usage_sentences: The building had a modern, rectilineal design.
A square is a rectilineal figure with four equal sides.

12.meaning_en: Occurring often or repeatedly.
usage_sentences: He suffered from recurrent nightmares after the traumatic event.
A recurrent theme in her novels is the search for identity.

12.meaning_en: (Noun) - An action that is performed as an automatic response to a stimulus and without conscious thought.
usage_sentences: The doctor tested the patient's reflexes by tapping his knee.
Pulling your hand away from a hot object is a reflex action.

12.meaning_en: The doctrine that reform is the best approach to social and political problems.
usage_sentences: His political philosophy was based on gradual reformism, not revolution.
The party's reformism attracted moderate voters.

12.meaning_en: A person who has been forced to leave their country in order to escape war, persecution, or natural disaster.
usage_sentences: Thousands of refugees fled the war-torn country.
The camp was set up to provide shelter for the refugees.

12.meaning_en: The killing of a king.
usage_sentences: The plot to commit regicide was discovered before it could be carried out.
The execution of King Charles I in England was an act of regicide.

12.meaning_en: Restore (someone) to health or normal life by training and therapy after imprisonment, addiction, or illness.
usage_sentences: The program helps to rehabilitate prisoners so they can rejoin society.
After the injury, the athlete worked hard to rehabilitate his knee.
12.origin: From medieval Latin 'rehabilitare', from 're-' (again) and 'habilitare' (to make able).

12.meaning_en: Make (someone or something) look or feel younger, fresher, or more lively.
usage_sentences: A week's vacation in the mountains completely rejuvenated him.
The new manager's task is to rejuvenate the struggling company.

12.meaning_en: Unwilling and hesitant; disinclined.
usage_sentences: He was reluctant to admit that he had made a mistake.
She seemed reluctant to talk about her past.

12.meaning_en: Deep and painful regret for wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: He felt a deep sense of remorse for what he had done.
The defendant showed no remorse for his crimes during the trial.
12.origin: From Old French 'remors', from Latin 'remordere' (to bite back).

12.meaning_en: Restore (something old, especially a building) to a good state of repair.
usage_sentences: They decided to renovate their old kitchen.
The historic hotel has been beautifully renovated.

12.meaning_en: Sincere regret or remorse.
usage_sentences: In his letter, he expressed deep repentance for his actions.
True repentance involves a change in behavior, not just words.
12.origin: From Old French 'repentance', from the verb 'repentir'.

12.meaning_en: Restore (a stock or supply) to a former level or condition.
usage_sentences: You need to drink plenty of water to replenish the fluids lost through sweat.
After the party, we had to replenish our stock of food and drinks.
12.origin: From Old French 'replenir', meaning 'to fill up again'.

12.meaning_en: An exact copy or model of something, especially one on a smaller scale.
usage_sentences: The museum has a full-scale replica of a dinosaur skeleton.
He built a perfect replica of the famous ship.

12.meaning_en: A class of cold-blooded vertebrate animals that includes tortoises, turtles, snakes, lizards, crocodiles, and alligators.
usage_sentences: Snakes and lizards are both types of reptiles.
Most reptiles lay eggs, though some give birth to live young.

12.meaning_en: Arousing intense distaste or disgust.
usage_sentences: There was a repulsive smell coming from the rotten food.
I find his cruel behavior utterly repulsive.
12.origin: From late Latin 'repulsivus', from 'repellere' (to drive back).

12.meaning_en: Someone who is slow to reveal emotion or opinions.
usage_sentences: He is a very reserved person and doesn't talk much about himself.
Although she seems like a reserved person at first, she is very friendly.
12.origin: From the verb 'reserve', from Latin 'reservare' (to keep back).

12.meaning_en: A large natural or artificial lake used as a source of water supply.
usage_sentences: The city gets its drinking water from a large reservoir in the hills.
The reservoir was created by building a dam across the river.

12.meaning_en: The process of breathing.
usage_sentences: The patient's respiration became slow and shallow.
Cellular respiration is the process by which cells get energy from food.

13.meaning_en: Make an attack in return for a similar attack.
usage_sentences: The army promised to retaliate against any further attacks.
She decided not to retaliate, choosing instead to ignore his insults.

13.meaning_en: Go back over (the same route that one has just taken).
usage_sentences: He had to retrace his steps to find his lost keys.
The detective asked the witness to retrace her movements on the day of the crime.

13.meaning_en: (Verb) - Withdraw from enemy forces as a result of their superior power or after a defeat. (Noun) - The act of withdrawing from enemy forces.
usage_sentences: The defeated army was forced to retreat.
She went on a yoga retreat to relax and de-stress.
13.origin: From Old French 'retrait', from 'retraire' (to pull back).

13.meaning_en: A scale of numbers used to express the magnitude of earthquakes.
usage_sentences: The earthquake measured 7.8 on the Richter scale.
The Richter scale is logarithmic, so a magnitude 6 earthquake is ten times stronger than a magnitude 5.
13.origin: Named after Charles F. Richter, the American seismologist who developed it.

13.meaning_en: (Verb) - Subject (someone or something) to contemptuous and dismissive language or behavior. (Noun) - The subjection of someone or something to contemptuous and dismissive language or behavior.
usage_sentences: He was subjected to ridicule for his unusual ideas.
It is unkind to ridicule someone for their mistakes.

13.meaning_en: Unable to bend or be forced out of shape; not flexible.
usage_sentences: The company has very rigid rules about punctuality.
He maintained a rigid posture throughout the interview.

13.meaning_en: A religious or other solemn ceremony or act.
usage_sentences: The funeral rites were performed according to ancient traditions.
Many cultures have special rites of passage to mark the transition to adulthood.
13.origin: From Latin 'ritus', meaning 'religious observance or ceremony'.

13.meaning_en: (Verb) - Move with urgent haste. (Noun) - An act of moving with urgent haste.
usage_sentences: He had to rush to catch the last train home.
There's no need to rush; we have plenty of time.
13.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'russer', related to Old French 'reuser' (to drive back).

13.meaning_en: A long story of heroic achievement, especially a medieval prose narrative in Norse or Icelandic.
usage_sentences: The movie trilogy was an epic saga of good versus evil.
He told us the long saga of his family's journey to America.
13.origin: From Old Norse, literally 'what is said, a narrative'.

13.meaning_en: The quality of being particularly noticeable or important; prominence.
usage_sentences: The salience of this issue has increased in recent years.
The report highlighted the salience of mental health in the workplace.

13.meaning_en: A place of refuge or safety.
usage_sentences: The wildlife sanctuary protects endangered species.
She sought sanctuary in the church to escape her pursuers.

13.meaning_en: A sacred place, especially a shrine within a temple or church.
usage_sentences: Only the high priest was allowed to enter the inner sanctum of the temple.
His study was his private sanctum, where he could work without being disturbed.
13.origin: From Latin, meaning 'holy place', from 'sancire' (to consecrate).

13.meaning_en: The use of irony to mock or convey contempt.
usage_sentences: His voice was full of sarcasm when he complimented my terrible singing.
She has a very dry wit and a talent for sarcasm.

13.meaning_en: The use of humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices.
usage_sentences: The show uses political satire to comment on current events.
Jonathan Swift's 'Gulliver's Travels' is a classic work of satire.
13.origin: From Latin 'satura (lanx)', meaning '(dish) of mixed fruits'.

13.meaning_en: An action or event regarded as morally or legally wrong and causing general public outrage.
usage_sentences: The politician was forced to resign after a major financial scandal.
The news of the scandal was on the front page of every newspaper.
13.origin: From Greek 'skandalon', meaning 'a cause of offense, a snare'.

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who is blamed for the wrongdoings, mistakes, or faults of others. (Verb) - Make a scapegoat of.
usage_sentences: He was made a scapegoat for the company's failures.
The manager tried to scapegoat his assistant to save his own job.
13.origin: From 'scape' (escape) + 'goat', a goat symbolically laden with the sins of the people and sent into the wilderness in the Bible.

13.meaning_en: The state of being scarce or in short supply; shortage.
usage_sentences: There is a scarcity of clean drinking water in the region.
The scarcity of resources led to conflict between the two tribes.

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - A plan of procedure, listing events and times. (Verb) - Arrange or plan (an event) to take place at a particular time.
usage_sentences: My schedule for next week is already completely full.
The meeting is scheduled for 10 a.m. on Monday.
13.origin: From late Latin 'schedula', a diminutive of 'scheda' (papyrus strip).

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - Academic study or achievement; learning of a high level. (Noun) - A grant or payment made to support a student's education, awarded on the basis of academic or other achievement.
usage_sentences: She won a scholarship to study at a prestigious university.
His book is a great work of historical scholarship.

13.meaning_en: Not connected with religious or spiritual matters.
usage_sentences: India is a secular country, with no official state religion.
She prefers to listen to secular music rather than religious hymns.
13.origin: From Latin 'saecularis', meaning 'relating to an age or period'.

13.meaning_en: An instrument that measures and records details of earthquakes, such as force and duration.
usage_sentences: The seismograph detected a minor tremor early this morning.
Data from seismographs around the world helps scientists study earthquakes.

13.meaning_en: The branch of science concerned with earthquakes and related phenomena.
usage_sentences: He is a professor of seismology at the university.
Seismology helps us to understand the forces that shape our planet.

13.meaning_en: Take hold of suddenly and forcibly.
usage_sentences: The police will seize the illegal goods.
You have to seize the opportunity when it comes.
13.origin: From Old French 'saisir', of Germanic origin.

13.meaning_en: Not often; rarely.
usage_sentences: We seldom see our cousins who live in another country.
He is seldom late for his appointments.
13.origin: From Old English 'seldan', of Germanic origin.

13.meaning_en: A conference or other meeting for discussion or training.
usage_sentences: I attended a seminar on digital marketing last week.
The professor will hold a seminar for graduate students.

13.meaning_en: Quick to detect or respond to slight changes, signals, or influences.
usage_sentences: My skin is very sensitive to the sun.
You need to be sensitive when discussing this topic.

13.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Consisting of, forming part of, or taking place in a series. (Noun) - A story or play appearing in regular installments in a magazine or newspaper, or broadcast on television or radio.
usage_sentences: The police are searching for a serial killer.
Charles Dickens' novels were originally published as serials in magazines.

13.meaning_en: The production of raw silk by raising silkworms.
usage_sentences: Sericulture is an important industry in many parts of Asia.
The process of sericulture involves cultivating mulberry leaves for silkworms to eat.

13.meaning_en: A close-fitting cover for something, especially the blade of a knife or sword.
usage_sentences: The warrior drew his sword from its sheath.
The electrician removed the plastic sheath from the wire.
13.origin: From Old English 'scēath', of Germanic origin.

13.meaning_en: Having or showing sharp powers of judgment; astute.
usage_sentences: He was a shrewd businessman who made a fortune in real estate.
She made a shrewd decision to invest in the new company.

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - A form of transport, especially a bus or train, that travels regularly between two places. (Verb) - Travel regularly between two places.
usage_sentences: The hotel provides a free shuttle service to the airport.
The space shuttle was used for many missions into orbit.
13.origin: From Old English 'scytel', meaning 'dart, missile', related to 'shoot'.

13.meaning_en: A figure of speech involving the comparison of one thing with another thing of a different kind, used to make a description more emphatic or vivid.
usage_sentences: 'As brave as a lion' is a well-known simile.
The poet used a beautiful simile to describe the sunset.

13.meaning_en: Occurring or operating at the same time.
usage_sentences: There were several simultaneous attacks on different cities.
The movie will have a simultaneous release in cinemas and on streaming platforms.
13.origin: From medieval Latin 'simultaneus', from 'simul' (at the same time).

13.meaning_en: An internal or external framework of bone, cartilage, or other rigid material supporting or protecting the body of an animal or plant.
usage_sentences: The human skeleton is made up of 206 bones.
Archaeologists unearthed the complete skeleton of a mammoth.

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - A narrow opening or groove in something. (Verb) - Fit into a slot.
usage_sentences: Please insert your ticket into the slot on the machine.
I've managed to find a slot in my schedule for a meeting.
13.origin: From Old French 'esclot', the hollow of the breastbone.

13.meaning_en: The study of the development, structure, and functioning of human society.
usage_sentences: She is studying sociology to understand the causes of social inequality.
Sociology examines how people interact in groups.

13.meaning_en: The state or situation of being alone.
usage_sentences: He enjoys the peace and solitude of the countryside.
After a busy week, she looked forward to a weekend of solitude.

13.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Able to pay one's debts. (Noun) - The liquid in which a solute is dissolved to form a solution.
usage_sentences: The company managed to remain solvent during the economic crisis.
Water is often called the universal solvent.

13.meaning_en: The forming of a theory or conjecture without firm evidence.
usage_sentences: There has been much speculation in the media about the couple's relationship.
His theory is pure speculation and is not supported by any facts.

13.meaning_en: A person who speaks for a group or organization.
usage_sentences: A spokesman for the company issued a statement to the press.
The government spokesman refused to comment on the matter.
13.origin: A compound of 'spoke' (past tense of speak) and 'man'.

13.meaning_en: Plural form of Spokesman.
usage_sentences: Spokespersons from both political parties debated the issue on television.
The company appointed two spokespersons to handle media inquiries.

13.meaning_en: A printed or computer-generated record of the balance in an account.
usage_sentences: I receive a monthly bank statement showing all my transactions.
Please check your credit card statement for any errors.
13.origin: From the verb 'state', from Latin 'stare' (to stand).

13.meaning_en: Not able to produce children or young.
usage_sentences: The doctor confirmed that the infection had left him sterile.
Surgical instruments must be completely sterile before use.

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining. (Adjective) - Enduring hardship without showing feelings or complaining.
usage_sentences: He remained stoic throughout the long and painful ordeal.
She was a true stoic, never complaining despite her illness.
13.origin: From Greek 'Stōïkos', from 'Stoa (Poikilē)' (Painted Porch), the place in Athens where the philosopher Zeno taught.

13.meaning_en: The endurance of pain or hardship without a display of feelings and without complaint.
usage_sentences: He faced the difficult situation with admirable stoicism.
Stoicism was an ancient Greek school of philosophy.

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - Mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or demanding circumstances. (Verb) - Subject to stress or tension.
usage_sentences: Working long hours can cause a lot of stress.
The teacher stressed the importance of studying for the exam.

13.meaning_en: Demanding that rules concerning behavior are obeyed and observed.
usage_sentences: The school has a strict policy against bullying.
Her parents were very strict when she was a child.

13.meaning_en: Arrange to receive something regularly by paying a subscription.
usage_sentences: I subscribe to several magazines about science and technology.
You can subscribe to our YouTube channel to get notifications for new videos.

13.meaning_en: (Especially of a change or distinction) so delicate or fine as to be difficult to perceive or describe.
usage_sentences: There was a subtle change in his tone of voice.
The artist is known for her subtle use of color.
13.origin: From Old French 'soutil', from Latin 'subtilis' (fine, delicate).

13.meaning_en: (Noun) - The act of intentionally causing one's own death. (Verb) - Intentionally cause one's own death.
usage_sentences: The note he left made it clear that his death was a suicide.
Mental health support is crucial in preventing suicide.
13.origin: From modern Latin 'suicidium', from 'sui' (of oneself) and '-cidium' (a killing).

14.meaning_en: A brief statement or account of the main points of something.
usage_sentences: Please provide a one-page summary of the report.
In summary, the project was a great success.

14.meaning_en: Existing or occurring at or on the surface.
usage_sentences: The doctor said the wound was only superficial and didn't require stitches.
He has only a superficial knowledge of the subject.

14.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Of the highest quality or degree. (Noun) - An exaggerated or hyperbolical expression of praise.
usage_sentences: The chef's cooking was of superlative quality.
In grammar, 'best' is the superlative form of 'good'.

14.meaning_en: Involving or denoting a speed greater than that of sound.
usage_sentences: The Concorde was a famous supersonic passenger jet.
The fighter jet created a sonic boom as it flew at supersonic speeds.

14.meaning_en: Excessively credulous belief in and reverence for supernatural beings.
usage_sentences: It's a common superstition that breaking a mirror brings seven years of bad luck.
He dismissed her fears as mere superstition.
14.origin: From Latin 'superstitio(n-)', from 'superstare' (to stand over in awe).

14.meaning_en: The state or condition of being superior to all others in authority, power, or status.
usage_sentences: The company has achieved supremacy in the global market.
The battle was fought to establish naval supremacy.

14.meaning_en: (Noun) - A sudden large increase, typically temporary. (Verb) - (of a crowd or a natural force) move suddenly and powerfully forward or upward.
usage_sentences: There has been a surge in demand for electric cars.
The crowd surged forward to get a better view.

14.meaning_en: (Noun) - An amount of something left over when requirements have been met; an excess of production or supply over demand. (Adjective) - More than what is needed or used; excess.
usage_sentences: The country has a trade surplus, exporting more than it imports.
Any surplus food from the event will be donated to charity.

14.meaning_en: (Verb) - Stop resisting to an enemy or opponent and submit to their authority. (Noun) - The action of surrendering.
usage_sentences: The enemy forces were finally forced to surrender.
He refused to surrender his dreams, despite the setbacks.

14.meaning_en: A weapon with a long metal blade and a hilt with a hand guard, used for thrusting or striking.
